{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "nr": 1, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-12T03:00:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gd6v7134AUa", "data": "lq1r9f52j6m3y", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-12T03:00:42Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gd6v7134AUa", "subject": "Welcome to Piazza!", "created": "2023-12-12T03:00:42Z", "content": " Piazza is a Q&A platform designed to get you great answers from classmates and instructors fast. We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started:
  1. Ask questions! The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are).
  2. Edit questions and answers wiki-style. Think of Piazza as a Q&A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single students' answer that students can edit collectively (and a single instructors’ answer for instructors).
  3. Add a followup to comment or ask further questions. To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a followup discussion. Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&A above.
  4. Go anonymous. Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously.
  5. Tag your posts. It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a “#” before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag.
  6. Format code and equations. Adding a code snippet? Click the pre or tt button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. Mathematical equation? Click the Fx button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation.
  7. View and download class details and resources.
Click the Course Page button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources—all in one place! Contact the Piazza Team anytime with questions or comments at team@piazza.com. Instructors and TAs will be monitoring Piazza regularly.

I strongly encourage students to help each other. Up to 2 bonus marks will be given to the top ten student answerers.

**Rules for participation:**

1- Clearly state your question. Showing just a picture, or writing "It's not working, and I don't know why" may not get the attention it deserves. State what is the problem exactly, and it is ideal if you state what you think caused it.

2- Don't post code. If someone copies code you sent on Piazza, this constitutions as an academic integrity violation for the copier and the provider. If you want to show code, post a private post to the instructors.

Wishing you all the best,

{"history_size": 2, "folders": ["logistics", "general_questions"], "nr": 29, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-08T05:51:48Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lr4i9gqpzyq457", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-08T05:51:48Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lr4icnqp4y86a5", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-01-08T05:54:17Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "How to fix the "no such file or directory" debugger error", "created": "2024-01-08T05:54:17Z", "content": "

(This post is bilingual because the problem mainly affects non-English students / Ce post est bilangue parce que le problème touche principalement les élèves non anglophone)

There is a known problem with the GDB debugger for Windows (MinGW GDB) where it cannot access files whose path contains non-ASCII characters. / Il y a une problème connue avec le débogueur GDB pour Windows (MinGW GDB) où il ne peut pas accéder des fichiers dont le chemin d'accès contient des caractères non ASCII.

If you don't want to (or can't) change the folder or file name, you can use the following instructions to fix the error (but you'll need administrative permissions). / Si vous ne voulez pas (ou ne pouvez pas) modifier le nom du dossier ou du fichier, vous pouvez utiliser les instructions suivantes pour arranger l'erreur (mais vous auriez besoin des permissions administratives).

Go to Control Panel > Clock and Region > Region > Administration and click on "Change system locale...". Then activate the "Beta: Use Unicode UTF-8 for worldwide language support" option and restart your computer. / Naviguez au Panneau de configuration > Horloge et région > Région > Administration et appuyez sur « Modifier les paramètres régionaux... ». Puis activez l'option « Beta: Use Unicode UTF-8 for worldwide language support » et redémarrez votre ordinateur.

Now the error should be resolved and you can continue to follow the instructions in lab 0. / Maintenant l'erreur devrait être résolue et vous pouvez continuer à suivre les instructions de labo 0.

I hope this helps. / J'espère que cela vous aidez.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "How to fix the "no such file or directory" debugger error", "created": "2024-01-08T05:51:48Z", "content": "

(This post is bilingual because the problem mainly affects non-English students / Ce post est bilangue parce que le problème touche principalement les élèves non anglophone)

There is a known problem with the GDB debugger for Windows (MinGW GDB) where it cannot access files whose path contains accents. / Il y a une problème connue avec le débogueur GDB pour Windows (MinGW GDB) où il ne peut pas accéder des fichiers dont le chemin d'accès contient des accents.

If you don't want to (or can't) change the folder or file name, you can use the following instructions to fix the error (but you'll need administrative permissions). / Si vous ne voulez pas (ou ne pouvez pas) modifier le nom du dossier ou du fichier, vous pouvez utiliser les instructions suivantes pour arranger l'erreur (mais vous auriez besoin des permissions administratives).

Go to Control Panel > Clock and Region > Region > Administration and click on "Change system locale...". Then activate the "Beta: Use Unicode UTF-8 for worldwide language support" option and restart your computer. / Naviguez au Panneau de configuration > Horloge et région > Région > Administration et appuyez sur « Modifier les paramètres régionaux... ». Puis activez l'option « Beta: Use Unicode UTF-8 for worldwide language support » et redémarrez votre ordinateur.

Now the error should be resolved and you can continue to follow the instructions in lab 0. / Maintenant l'erreur devrait être résolue et vous pouvez continuer à suivre les instructions de labo 0.

I hope this helps. / J'espère que cela vous aidez.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lab0"], "nr": 30, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-08T14:10:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lr50397ceuw6f8", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-08T14:10:51Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "to": "lr503977k1e6f7", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-01-08T14:24:35Z", "cid": "lr50kwrpyuh4r5"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "data": "lr51m027pil5cq", "to": "lr503977k1e6f7", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-08T14:53:26Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Purpose of Debugger", "created": "2024-01-08T14:10:51Z", "content": "

Hello,

I had a question about the window that pops up when you run the debugger. I assumed that the debugger would show me the error in my code, but now it seems that the window simply displays the last compiled version of my code. So now I am confused as to what the purpose of that window is. 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab0", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 102, "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Can you display an image of the window you're talking about? When you start the debugger, there will be two windows: VS Code and a terminal.", "created": "2024-01-08T14:24:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lr50kwrpyuh4r5", "updated": "2024-01-09T00:45:24Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-08T14:53:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Ruth Fasil", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llzr7adf3zk2u8", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Allie Okumura", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljyfjfgr72r4n0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-08T14:53:26Z", "content": "

I believe the window that pops up when debugging just shows the output of your compiled code.

 

From what I understand, the debugger won’t necessarily tell you where the errors in your code are. When you have syntax errors (i.e., pritf(“Hello world”); instead of printf(“Hello world”);), you’ll get an error message in the terminal and can use that to fix the mistake.

However, the debugger can be used to identify the logical errors (errors in the code that is syntactically correct, but produces incorrect results). This can be done by setting breakpoints, which allow you to stop program execution at a specified point. From there you can examine the state of your program (i.e., values of variables) and can even run your code step-by-step to pinpoint the source of the error. It's useful for understanding your code and what each line does.

I'm having the same issue and I'm a complete newbie to all this stuff!", "created": "2024-01-11T21:52:29Z", "bucket_order": 8, "bucket_name": "Week 1/7 - 1/13", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lr9qwh2h2231js", "updated": "2024-01-11T21:52:29Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "As far as I know these are what cause the issue:

- Didn't establish the directory properly under "edit environment variables"
- Didn't install gcc properly
- Didn't compile code before trying to run it
- C/C++ runner extension's directory was set to the wrong thing, make sure the first box is set to just: "gcc" when you go to edit the extension

Also make sure to try deleting the .vscode file if you have changed anything I've previously said (scroll up a bit if you don't know what I am referring to) it will automatically regenerate even thought the option says: "Delete permanently"

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lab1"], "nr": 60, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-09T18:08:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llyhj9awro63lb", "data": "lr6o0osy8uv4a8", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-09T18:08:29Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevc7iza7in11p", "data": "lr6qatlarr96zp", "to": "lr6o0osut0l4a7", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-09T19:12:21Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llyhj9awro63lb", "subject": "Lab 1 Part 2: Rounding convention", "created": "2024-01-09T18:08:29Z", "content": "

Lab 1 part 2 states:

All output temperatures should be rounded to one decimal place. No
more than one decimal place should be displayed for the result.

What is the expected rounding convention? printf, I believe, performs "Banker's rounding"/"round ties to even" (at least this is the rounding convention specified by IEEE-754, which I would expect C99 and later standards follow). Alternatively, there is half-up rounding, as well as others.

Thanks!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 100, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-09T19:12:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Salma Emara", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": "1675320204_200.jpg", "id": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/jlzv60dhucu1fm/1675320204_200.jpg", "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Boris Potapov", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llyhj9awro63lb", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevc7iza7in11p", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-09T19:12:21Z", "content": "i think you can get a sense of the rounding just based off of the auto tester. i included <math.h> and then tried to use M_PI but it says the identifier is undefined, what should i do?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 123, "children": [{"history_size": 8, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-09T20:46:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Huda Halani", "endorser": {"ljajlq9tev95ta": 1692840530}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljok79rjfz34p", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Lily Chen", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llgvmgp9ws25xe", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llyhj9awro63lb", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-09T21:28:52Z", "content": "

Assuming that you are observing this in VSCode editor, you might need to change the "cStandard" property in "configurations" array in c_cpp_properties.json file to "gnu17" (or "gnu23").

The reason for this is because this setting apparently defaults to "c99", in which M_PI is indeed not defined. GNU's compiler provides a bunch of extensions to the standard C.

your code your choice :).

As long as you’re not doing something outlandish like making a C wrapper that calls a python script because you hate C or something like that then you can do whatever you please or including some library that does the entire lab (shouldn’t be possible) in one or two lines

So yes to your first question unless it says you cannot modify anything in the lab handout 

Comments are not marked, you can choose to leave them there or not but in general they’re helpful especially if you want to look back on your code and figure out what you did (we often forget)

As long as you’re not doing something outlandish like making a C wrapper that calls a python script because you hate C or something like that then you can do whatever you please or including some library that does the entire lab (shouldn’t be possible) in one or two lines

So yes to your first question 

Comments are not marked, you can choose to leave them there or not but in general they’re helpful especially if you want to look back on your code and figure out what you did (we often forget)

For lab1part1 you have to write a code that prints the code that is used to write hello world..

In C, the program to print "hello, world" is
#include <stdio.h>
int main(void) {
printf("hello, world\n");
return 0;
}

You have to write a code so as to get the output mentioned in bold above, hope it helped :)

It is hard to diagnose the issue with the limited error trace provided, however I was able to find a reported issue with a similar stack trace as yours, however my knowledge of extension architecture is quite limited so my judgement may be incorrect. It appears that it might be related to the failure to install VS code server instance on the ECF host. The recommended solution is to invoke the "Kill VSCode server on host" command (you can hit Ctrl+Shift+P, and start typing "Kill VSCode...", then hit enter key):

can you run the command kill vscode server on host from the command palette then try setup again? This might reset the situation to allow the install to go smoothly.

However, I would encourage you to post the entire output log to help pin point the issue precisely. Be sure to remove any sensitive output from the log before submitting it to piazza.

Question 1: In Lab 1, my code compiles with gcc lab1part2.c -o lab1part2 -lm. However, it doesn't when I submit my code. Why?

Answer 1: You shouldn't use the math library in lab 1 part 1, 2 or 4. Use the math library only for lab 1 part 3.

Question 2: In Lab 1 part 3, VS Code is not compiling my code as it says sqrt or pow are undefined.

Answer 2: In the VS Code window, along with your folders you will find .vscode folder. Inside it, there is settings.json. Open the file and find, "C_Cpp_Runner.compilerArgs" and add -lm to it to make it look like this:

"C_Cpp_Runner.compilerArgs": ["-lm"],

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "subject": "Lab 1 - FAQ", "created": "2024-01-12T23:52:24Z", "content": "

Question: In Lab 1, my code compiles with gcc lab1part2.c -o lab1part2 -lm. However, it doesn't when I submit my code. Why?

Answer: You shouldn't use the math library in lab 1 part 1, 2 or 4. Use the math library only for lab 1 part 3.

Question: In Lab 1 part 3, VS Code is not compiling my code as it says sqrt or pow are undefined.

Answer: In the VS Code window, along with your folders you will find .vscode folder. Inside it, there is settings.json. Open the file and find, "C_Cpp_Runner.compilerArgs" and add -lm to it to make it look like this:

"C_Cpp_Runner.compilerArgs": ["-lm"],

I found that the prompts required for this part is inconsistent on the autograder and the lab handout. 

On the lab handout, we are asked to use:

Enter the circumference (km) of the planet: 

Enter the acceleration due to gravity (m/s^2) on the planet: 

However, in the ECF autograder, it shows that the correct prompts are:

Circumference (km) of planet?

Acceleration due to gravity (m/s^2) on planet?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab1", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Puneet Dhaliwal", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llzx0g20w9a3ec", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Suzen Bao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukh5cyqz224", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 97, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-11T23:52:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Bans Kim", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "kf3z1m0t7zlbg", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llyhj9awro63lb", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-11T23:52:47Z", "content": "Make sure you include the -lm switch when invoking the gcc command on ECF machine."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["kf3z1m0t7zlbg"], "children": [], "id": "lr9v76hsfd1727", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-12T00:06:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Manahil Saeed", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm562039i1l1bg", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkv5y3sefcf2ds", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-12T00:09:27Z", "content": "

In certain environments, the math library is not included during the linking process while compilation. So, you have to explicitly tell the compiler to link it by adding the -lm flag to the compilation command as the following.

gcc programName.c -lm -o programName

For more details about compilation and linking on C, please refer to this article, https://wahyu-ehs.medium.com/compiling-and-linking-on-c-programming-b22eb634d27

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkv5y3sefcf2ds", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-12T00:06:19Z", "content": "

In certain enviroments, the math library is not included during the linking process while compilation. So, you have to explicitly tell the compiler to link it by adding the -lm flag in the compilation command. 
gcc program.c -lm -o program

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm562039i1l1bg"], "children": [], "id": "lr9vokuodsl64i", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["llzx0g20w9a3ec", "lm7ukh5cyqz224"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lr9uy94rpax3kr", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716162423760, "default_anonymity": "no"}

A few pointers could help-
1. Make sure that you include -lm at the end of your code i.e gcc -o output_file input_file.c -lm, it'll help the compiler link the math function used.
3. Recheck your gcc command to make sure that there are no missing files or typos

4. Maybe recheck your compiler version through gcc --version

5. Try restarting the terminal and see if that helps

6. see for an typos

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["general_questions"], "nr": 133, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-13T03:37:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrbio5zujlt6ll", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-13T03:37:37Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "data": "lrbiwjr3ypq4hc", "to": "lrbio5zraia6lk", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-13T03:44:08Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Snefru 2.2 Quiz question 2", "created": "2024-01-13T03:37:37Z", "content": "

Aren't 1,0,5 also integers? So why can't %d be used in this case?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["general_questions", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 60, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-13T03:44:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Angelina Zhu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukgfqdy6208", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-13T03:44:08Z", "content": "

In this case, '1', '0', and '5' are of the character type (due to the single quotations). When we are using the integer format specifier (%d) on a character, the program will convert the character into its equivalent ASCII code. If you were to test it out, the output would be "The course number is APS494853". You can look up its equivalent code in a table such as the following (left column is ASCII code in decimal, right column is the character):

Note that this corresponds to '1' = 49, '0' = 48, '5' = 53, which is what you see printed.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukgfqdy6208"], "children": [], "id": "lrbiwjqyphw4hb", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrbio5zraia6lk", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 1, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716162445375, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["general_questions"], "nr": 134, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-13T06:46:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "l7tdlic4pkg326", "data": "lrbpfbbm4781np", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-13T06:46:41Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ljtubawzb0147n", "data": "lrcasfrt3yr77i", "to": "lrbpfbbjfw21no", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-13T16:44:46Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "data": "lrccji12jsa6cq", "to": "lrbpfbbjfw21no", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-13T17:33:48Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "data": "lrcckw0vbre7ic", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-01-13T17:34:53Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "l7tdlic4pkg326", "subject": "Addresses and & usage", "created": "2024-01-13T06:46:41Z", "content": "

Hello,

I just wanted some clarification on the use of &. When using scanf, you are required to specify the format specifier as well as the variable so it looks like this for example:

scanf("%d", &pizza) ;

from my understanding, & accesses the variable's address so is the users input being stored in place of the address or the address' corresponding value? 

Additionally, once we initialize a variable, why do we not use the & to define a value for it. For example why do we do 

int pizza, slice;

pizza = 8;

slice = pizza*8 ;

and not:

int pizza, slice;

&pizza = 8

&slice = pizza*8

Hopefully my questions make sense! Thank you in advance

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["general_questions", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 58, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-13T16:44:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljtubawzb0147n", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-13T16:44:46Z", "content": "

in the scanf function '&' operator is used to fetch the address of the variable where values entered by the user or simply the user input, should be stored. when you use '&pizza', you are directly providing the address of thre 'pizza' variable to 'scanf', so as a result the user input would be stored at the memory location of the variable 'pizza'

Answering your second question, when you initialize a variable, a value gets assigned to the variable directly. The code initializes the 'pizza' variable with the value of 8, '&' is not used in this context because you are not taking the address, instead you are assigning a value to a variable. If you use '&pizza' then it would result in a compilation error because the left side of the assignmed should be a variable and not an address, so '&pizza', is an address thats why we do not use it.

Hopefully it helps..

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrcasfrpijg77h", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-13T17:33:48Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Salma Emara", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": "1675320204_200.jpg", "id": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/jlzv60dhucu1fm/1675320204_200.jpg", "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-13T17:34:53Z", "content": "You will know a lot more when we talk about address in the future. That is a very big topic and could say the most important/useful/painful feature that C/C++ has but most other programming languages don't."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-13T17:33:48Z", "content": "You will know a lot more when we talk about address in the future. That is a very big topic."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["jlzv60dhucu1fm"], "children": [], "id": "lrccji117c16cp", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrbpfbbjfw21no", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716162446406, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lab1"], "nr": 135, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-13T16:07:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrc9fx7fa0hlq", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-13T16:07:02Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llyo6kxhoi93sg", "data": "lrc9n8nr5v582", "to": "lrc9fx7bij3lp", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-13T16:12:44Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lrc9fx7bij3lp", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-01-13T21:54:53Z", "cid": "lrclv9khnbk2ta", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "to": "lrc9fx7bij3lp", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-01-13T21:58:28Z", "cid": "lrclzuzp65a3lw"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lrc9fx7bij3lp", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-01-13T22:00:41Z", "cid": "lrcm2pmvrbs47b", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Lab 1 Part 2", "created": "2024-01-13T16:07:02Z", "content": "

When I was reading over the instructions, there is something weird about the outputs in this example. The instructions state that we have to display the difference in degrees fahrenheit, but the difference is not in degrees fahrenheit. When I calculated the difference in this example, it was 3.7 degrees celsius. In fahrenheit, that would be around 38.66 not 6.7. Is my interpretation of the instructions false or is this example incorrect?\u00a0

\n

\n

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab1", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Alec Chen", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk4vzx1rv4", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 84, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-13T16:12:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Salma Emara", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": "1675320204_200.jpg", "id": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/jlzv60dhucu1fm/1675320204_200.jpg", "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Alec Chen", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk4vzx1rv4", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llyo6kxhoi93sg", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-13T16:12:44Z", "content": "Good question. The explanation you provided is false since this is not how you calculate the difference in Fahrenheit. Instead, first convert 22 deg C to 71.6 def F. Then, subtract 71.6 from 78.3 to yield 6.7 deg F. Therefore, the example is indeed correct."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["jlzv60dhucu1fm", "lm7uk4vzx1rv4"], "children": [], "id": "lrc9n8nokf6580", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "If we are given hints about how to approach the problem, would this is considered an academic violation, or is the act of copying/sharing code an academic violation?", "created": "2024-01-13T21:54:53Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "The syllabus states that we are allowed to discuss our approaches to problems: ", "created": "2024-01-13T21:58:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Salma Emara", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": "1675320204_200.jpg", "id": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/jlzv60dhucu1fm/1675320204_200.jpg", "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Alec Chen", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk4vzx1rv4", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["jlzv60dhucu1fm", "lm7uk4vzx1rv4"], "id": "lrclzuzp65a3lw", "updated": "2024-01-16T14:10:04Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Ok. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["general_questions"], "nr": 140, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-13T22:17:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrcmo0ks5c1vu", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-13T22:17:15Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevc7iza7in11p", "data": "lrcmuyl5gbc5cc", "to": "lrcmo0knc0b1vt", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-13T22:22:39Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevc7iza7in11p", "data": "lrcoeytpus97or", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-01-13T23:06:12Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "textbook1.2", "created": "2024-01-13T22:17:15Z", "content": "why the bit on the left is "four's bit"? There are only three bits."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["general_questions", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 47, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-13T22:22:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Linda Gao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm44343jfuy70y", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevc7iza7in11p", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-13T23:06:12Z", "content": "

It means the place value in binary for that value, not how many bits are there.

Binary goes from

1,2,4,8,16,32,64, etc

but increases from right to left so it would be 

etc, 64, 32, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1

The most significant bit (3 bits total) is equal to the value 4.

the one to the right of that would be called the two's bit and then the one's bit

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevc7iza7in11p", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-13T22:22:39Z", "content": "

It means the place value in binary for that value, not how many bits are there.

Binary goes from

1,2,4,8,16,32,64, etc

but increases from right to left so it would be 

etc, 64, 32, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1

The most significant bit (3 bits total) is the equals 4.

the one to the right of that would be called the two's bit and then the one's bit

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm44343jfuy70y"], "children": [], "id": "lrcmuyl1b3k5cb", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrcmo0knc0b1vt", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716162452584, "default_anonymity": "no"}

if you look at the build command you can see something like

gcc ... hello.o lab0.o -o out.exe

it seems that both of your files hello.c and lab0.c are being compiled into a single program, and I assume both of them have main functions. I'm not terribly familiar with the vs code build system but you might have put both files in the same project folder by mistake?

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["general_questions"], "nr": 166, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-16T01:53:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrfpa9wm5co6gw", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-16T01:53:51Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "data": "lrfpezwu3t64ta", "to": "lrfpa9wjw9m6gu", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-16T01:57:31Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "data": "lrfpn6blp6238s", "to": "lrfpa9wjw9m6gu", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-16T02:03:53Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Where does VS studio code return 0?", "created": "2024-01-16T01:53:51Z", "content": "

Hi, I'm having a slight trouble finding where the 0 is if the code executes successfully. Do you guys know where it is? I thought it would be in the output section of VS code but it'll only give an error. Thanks : ) 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["general_questions", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 55, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-16T01:57:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Joonho Jang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukxwtvpx3hs", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-16T01:57:31Z", "content": "I believe this value isn't outputted in the output or terminal, as it is something that is used by the operating system to see if your program ran successfully. If no errors (syntax related) come up, that means your program has run successfully."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukxwtvpx3hs"], "children": [], "id": "lrfpezwpwuk4t9", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-16T02:03:53Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Joonho Jang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukxwtvpx3hs", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-16T02:03:53Z", "content": "If your question is "Where is the 0 from `return 0;`?" It is not printed. Printed things are only printed through `printf`. We haven't yet discussed functions, so the following information is missing. It is a value that can be used to know if your code ran successfully. Try out return 1 (or any non-zero) number in VS Code. It will show that your code terminated with an exit code that is the same as the number you entered. Any non-zero number will result in a message saying your code exited with non-zero exit code. This signals something went wrong. If we reached a return 0. The code will stop executing, and exit code is 0 (meaning successful execution). ![image.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fjlzv60dhucu1fm%2Fb8472f751fa2b39b121c5c659a9654900f63c877e17c4b9558efb44e4a93b6bb%2Fimage.png)"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukxwtvpx3hs"], "children": [], "id": "lrfpn6bk3yy38r", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrfpa9wjw9m6gu", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716162479340, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Question 1: Do I assume the current time in part 2 will be a valid number?

Answer 1: Yes, assume all inputs are valid and 0 or positive in part 2. 

Question 2: When I enter the current time as 23 59 and trip time as 23.7, the arrival time is output as 23 40. The correct answer is 23 41. What did I do wrong? 

Answer 2: This is an issue with floating point precision error. 23.7 is stored as 23.69999.. and this can lead to issues in calculation. We are aware of that and have allowed a +/-1 minute from the correct answer in our expected output. 

Question 3: May I use the string library?

Answer 3: No, we haven't yet discussed that. You must only use characters. 

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevc7iza7in11p", "subject": "Lab 2 - FAQ", "created": "2024-01-19T14:49:39Z", "content": "

Question 1: Do I assume the current time in part 2 will be a valid number?

Answer 1: Yes, assume all inputs are valid and 0 or positive in part 2. 


NO STRING LIBRARY

Your lab1part1 is a subsection of lab1. That's the default way VS Code formats directories when there's only one folder inside of a folder.

File > Preferences > Settings > Features > Explore > Uncheck "Compact Folders"

If this issue is with all numbers, please post a private post with your code, and I will look into it. Or better, try using the debugger. It will show you what is stored in the numbers. 

I am afraid your issue is just with certain numbers. If this is the case, yes. `double` or `float` are not data types that store all numbers after the decimal place, so there is an issue with precision indeed. There are ways to avoid it, but it's too advanced for the course to discuss. This is one place that discusses this issue online: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/build/why-floating-point-numbers-may-lose-precision?view=msvc-170

I am asking this since the lab instructions do not specify whether a number like 5.55 will round to 5.6 or 5.5, or whether a number like 5.65 will round to 5.7 or 5.6."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab0", "lab1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 59, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-18T03:23:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-18T03:23:51Z", "content": "so if you have a number like 5.55 and assign it to int, it cuts off the number to appear as 5. To make something print as a certain number of decimal points, use %0.5lf, if you wanted to print 5 spaces. If 6, it would be 0.6 and lf is the specifier for double. Hope this helps :)"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrindq1zjpq22o", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Thanks for the reply, but that is not really what I was asking about. I was wondering whether a number such as 5.55 should round to 5.6 or 5.5 and whether 5.65 should round to 5.7 or 5.6. By using the rint() function, 5.55 can be made to round to 5.6 and 5.65 can be made to round to 5.6. Using the round() function, 5.55 can be made to round to 5.6 and 5.65 can be made to round to 5.7. Finally, using the format specifier (%.1lf), 5.55 will round to 5.5 and 5.65 will round to 5.6. As you can see, there are differences in the method used for rounding, so I was wondering what the expectations for rounding numbers in labs were.", "created": "2024-01-18T03:29:08Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "i think a lot of instructions say display result rounded to blah blah or print result rounded to blah blah so i think just using what ur classmate said should be okay? going to wait for a profs answer but for now don\u2019t stress about rounding too much, definitely not the biggest logical puzzle part of the lab\u00a0

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 46, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-19T01:48:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-19T01:51:29Z", "content": "

I have two questions that still confuses me after reading the posts at piazza:

(1) If I passed all the test cases in the submission part, then does it guarantee that I will get full marks? I know there are hidden test cases, but I am wondering if they are tested again after I submitted the code (which received "all passed" in the submission stage). 

(2) Also, for lab2 part3, should we take into account that r (distance between charges) be very large? (ex. 500 meters?). Because it would generate small value and appears 0nN when rounded to 2 decimal places. Or should we consider any Force value that is less than 0nN equals 0? 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 115, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-21T07:53:30Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-21T07:53:30Z", "content": "1- You guarantee to receive marks on the public test cases that you see. For example, in lab 1, there were 7 test cases in total shown to you. If you pass them, you guarantee 7/10. There are hidden test cases. 3 of them worth one mark each. If you pass them, you get 10/10.

2- Even if this is the case, your code should still output 0nN. 

Please follow up if it’s still unclear.

You can't type in the terminal, right? Try to click on the terminal and hit Enter

Can you try the following and see if you would be able to choose a different shell? 

  • As a workaround, you can change the default terminal in VS Code. Open the command palette (Ctrl + Shift + P), type Select Default Shell, and choose a different shell from the list. Can you please share the screenshot of this?


If the previous step didn't help, can you please try the following?

  • Open VS Code settings (JSON format) by pressing Ctrl + , and then clicking on the {} icon in the top right corner.
  • Look for the terminal.integrated.shell.* settings. You might see different settings for different OS like terminal.integrated.shell.windows, terminal.integrated.shell.linux, or terminal.integrated.shell.osx.
  • Ensure that the path to the shell executable is correct. For example, on Windows, it's often set to PowerShell or Command Prompt ("C:\\Windows\\System32\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\powershell.exe" or "C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe").

May I know why is there a 1 degree difference here? 

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Lab 3 Part 2: angles are off by 1 degree", "created": "2024-01-23T06:58:24Z", "content": "

Thanks everyone for spotting the error! It is indeed a typo from our side! I love the spirit of questioning the solution -- this is part of your (and my) educational journey! We should always be skeptical!

We fixed the handout on Quercus to show the correct angles, that are 46 (not 47), 18 (not 19) and 33 (not 34). The numbers changed are in red.

For those of you who already did the lab, we are considering the past incorrect answers to be correct too. I hope that counts as an appropriate compensation for the time you lost trying to figure out why is there a +1 to all angles. 

Thanks again for noticing the error! Have a wonderful day!

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-23T19:53:55Z", "content": "

Thanks everyone for spotting the error! It is indeed a typo from our side! I love the spirit of questioning the solution -- this is part of your (and mine) educational journey! We should always be skeptical!

We fixed the handout on Quercus to show the correct angles, that are 46 (not 47), 18 (not 19) and 33 (not 34). The numbers changed are in red.

For those of you who already did the lab, we are considering the past incorrect answers to be correct too. I hope that counts as an appropriate compensation for the time you lost trying to figure out why is there a +1 to all angles. 

Thanks again for noticing the error! Have a wonderful day!

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukyo3net3km", "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "llyhj9awro63lb", "lm7ul1bsu483t3"], "children": [], "id": "lrqry7xsdjz75h", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukyo3net3km", "ljpjslc4th91wm", "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "lm7ul1bsu483t3", "jlzv60dhucu1fm"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrq08w1rju84jh", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716162589602, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab3", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nithura Thevarajah", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk96a8bm1dp", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 83, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-24T13:53:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nithura Thevarajah", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk96a8bm1dp", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevc7iza7in11p", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-24T15:45:11Z", "content": "Can you please elaborate on how you figured out that the whitespace was the reason behind the unexpected behavior you experienced?

Also, can you screenshot an example(s) of the test cases that your code failed and what was your input?

Daniel:
It\u2019s because in lab2, you don\u2019t loop. So you never \u201crescan\u201d for characters so you won\u2019t have white space like a new line\u00a0
scanf(\u201c%c%c\u201d, &char1, &char2);
tells the program that i want to take two characters without skipping white space (new lines by clicking enter count!)
So when you enter something line\u00a0
-9<enter> on the first iteration it\u2019ll read the \u201c-\u201c and the \u201c9\u201d but on the second, it will read your new line (from your enter key) as the first.\u00a0
Thus, doing scanf(\u201c %c%c\u201d, &char1, &char2); tells the program to skip the white space before the first character\u00a0
"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevc7iza7in11p", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-24T15:44:40Z", "content": "Can you please elaborate on how you figured out that the whitespace was the reason behind the unexpected behavior you experienced?

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "lecture8 note", "created": "2024-01-25T04:38:34Z", "content": "

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["general_questions", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 53, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-25T05:23:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Mohamed Attia", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "lkv5y3sefcf2ds", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Salma Emara", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": "1675320204_200.jpg", "id": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/jlzv60dhucu1fm/1675320204_200.jpg", "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Linda Gao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm44343jfuy70y", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-25T05:28:15Z", "content": "

For this example, you can get the same results by using 3 if statements instead of using if + else if + else.

You can think of if + else if + else having mutually exclusive conditions (only one output will arise). Once it reaches a true condition, it will execute the corresponding code block and skip over the rest (the subsequent conditions will not be checked).

A sequence of if statements are independent of one another. Each condition is evaluated regardless if previous if statements are executed. This can have some implications, consider:

int x = 35;

if(x > 30) {

    printf("x > 30");

} else if(x > 20) {

    printf("x > 20");

} else {

    printf("x < 20");

}

The output will only be "x > 30", whereas if you use a sequence of if statements:

if(x > 30) {

    printf("x > 30");

}

if(x > 20) {

    printf("x > 20");

}

if(x > 10) {

    printf("x > 10");

}

The output of this would be:

"x > 30"

"x > 20"

"x > 10"

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-25T05:23:45Z", "content": "

You can think of if + else if + else has mutually exclusive conditions (only one output will arise). Once it reaches a true condition, it will execute the corresponding code block and skip over the rest (the subsequent conditions will not be checked).

@269 basically.

\n

Hi, 

I was wondering whether the first <enter> will be used in test cases? 

When I typed in the test case manually including the first <enter>, it passed all tests as I accounted for this strange <enter> by catching it in an unused char. However, when I went to do the public test cases with ~aps105i/etc, I noticed it failed and would only pass if I removed the catching the first enter. So is this a mistake in my code, or is there no <enter> before the first number? 

Thanks for your advice!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 89, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-31T01:10:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-31T01:10:04Z", "content": "There's an error in the way you're checking for lucky numbers. The handout states that a lucky number is one with exactly three 7s."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ls13br11dso7mn", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-31T01:11:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "l7peamq9ldd3rp", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-31T01:11:20Z", "content": "Exactly 3 7s, and a negative sign doesn't matter."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ls13ddvrj3r39o", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "So counting the number of 7s we see 12 were inputed, which means 4 lucky numbers ? ", "created": "2024-01-31T01:12:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Its for each input:

71237 - 2 (not lucky)

717717 - 4 (not lucky)

1727378 - 3 (lucky)

-1742797 - 3 (lucky)

", "created": "2024-01-31T01:14:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ls13hq8vjo511i", "updated": "2024-01-31T01:14:43Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

No, you need to find whether or not a number is lucky, and count the number of them. The group of numbers doesn't matter.

71237 has two 7 digits, it's not a lucky number

717717 has four 7 digits, it's not a lucky number

1727378 has three 7 digits, it's a lucky number

-1742797 has three 7 digits, it's a lucky number

Therefore 2 of the 4 numbers are lucky.

Hi, I have some questions about test cases/user input:

Hi everyone,

I was working on Lab 4 Part 1. When I finished my code, I tried running it in the VS Code on my laptop (not on remote ECF), trying the inputs from the examples given in the pdf, which were 10 and 100000. The output I got from running the program was different from the actual answers given in the pdf. I spent quite some time debugging but I could not find an error.

However, when I copied and pasted my code into the VS Code on the ECF remotely and ran it using the commands given in the pdf, I somehow got the correct answers; even though the test cases had the same inputs as the examples in the pdf.

TL:DR, I got different outputs when running on my laptop and running on the ECF. Is there an explanation for this discrepancy? Is it because the seed of rand() that is being run on different devices provides different values? Thank you in advance.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab4", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mahreen Naila", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uklh38no2ft", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 97, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-02T02:41:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nicholas Ghattas", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm5mvvq3q5n208", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-02T02:48:34Z", "content": "

Not incomplete, will generate ONE random double <=1.

The way this works is that rand() generates a random number from 0 to RAND_MAX. If we divide that result by RAND_MAX, we would get a result that is less than or equal to one (the values are casted to doubles so we don't run into integer division).

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-02T02:45:26Z", "content": "

Not incomplete, will generate ONE random double >=1.

Edit: It generates a random double that is less than or equal to 1.

The way this works is that rand() generates a random number from 0 to RAND_MAX. If we divide that result by RAND_MAX, we would get a result that is less than or equal to one (the values are casted to doubles so we don't run into integer division).

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lab3", "general_questions"], "nr": 377, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-02T04:42:33Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ls45spkkxc073a", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-02T04:42:33Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "data": "ls45w4n1j7d4kh", "to": "ls45spjyt62737", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-02T04:45:13Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "data": "ls45zne8ue22nv", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-02-02T04:47:57Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "arithmetic operator issue?", "created": "2024-02-02T04:42:33Z", "content": "

When trying to do the following arithmetic operation, the following error always occurs:

Why does result store 0?

(I've made sure to compile my code before using the debugger).

But when I change the (1/2)*(50) to 50/2, it yields the correct answer:

What am I doing wrong in the first scenario?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["general_questions", "lab3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 36, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-02T04:45:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Daniel Liu", "endorser": {"kex1d773m1q4wh": 1600385343, "keefchkgelh2ie": 1601352301, "kersxw4kjmi634": 1604633193, "global": 1604633193, "ks67upl5j2u636": 1638215275, "kxxhwvlztg1316": 1648301344, "kxrsgkty1i63uy": 1650402756, "l7jhttnojtu98": 1667170933, "lcl1hiw1lo02a5": 1678819708}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kevc7iza7in11p", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Angelina Zhu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukgfqdy6208", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-02T04:47:57Z", "content": "

It's because you are performing integer division. An integer is the most accurate data type involved in 1/2, so the quotient will be an integer. This means any decimal result will be truncated (0.5 turns into 0). To change this, you just need to make one the the operands a double (i.e. 1.0 / 2).

This section of the textbook discusses this: https://learningc.org/chapters/chapter02-variables/operations#the-more-accurate-data-type-is-contagious

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-02T04:45:13Z", "content": "It's because you are performing integer division. An integer is the most accurate data type involved in 1/2, so the quotient will be an integer. This means any decimal result will be truncated (0.5 turns into 0). To change this, you just need to make one the the operands a double (i.e. 1.0 / 2)"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["kevc7iza7in11p", "lm7ukgfqdy6208"], "children": [], "id": "ls45w4mt4k34kg", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls45spjyt62737", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 1, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716162696650, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Please clarify thanks "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["logistics", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 70, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-04T20:29:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jacky Zhao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lju72nwqwxz3ci", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-04T20:29:29Z", "content": "

Here's what I think:

- When we assign a variable to another variable, it only copies its value.

- When we assign a variable to a pointer, we assign its location in memory.

Therefore, when we update this pointer, we are directly changing whatever data is currently held in that location in the computer's memory.

In contrast, if we used a variable instead of a pointer, we are technically only updating the copied value that the computer has stored elsewhere, in an independent location.

Hopefully that makes sense.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lju72nwqwxz3ci"], "children": [], "id": "ls7yi5w8bahj2", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-04T21:17:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jacky Zhao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lju72nwqwxz3ci", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-04T21:17:06Z", "content": "

The student's answer is half correct and half incorrect.

The benefit of using a pointer is to mostly save memory space.

When you pass a value to a function, the value needs to be first copied and then passed to a function. When you pass a pointer to a function, only the pointer(the address to the value you want to pass into the function) needs to be copied. If the value you want to pass into a function takes a large chunk of memory space, then the benefit of using a pointer starts to show.

The student's answer says "if we used a variable instead of a pointer, we are technically only updating the copied value that the computer has stored elsewhere, in an independent location.", this is not accurate. When you update a value, you don't need to allocate a new chunk of memory. You still update the value in-place. The only time when you need a new memory space is to copy a value. I guess the student wants to say if you want to assign one variable to another new variable, then the statement is correct. However, keep in mind that pointer is just a type of variable, it also takes memory space.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lju72nwqwxz3ci"], "children": [], "id": "ls807em8vmx29r", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Thanks for the correction, Louis. ", "created": "2024-02-04T23:25:50Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls84syvhjcm1c6", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-02-04T23:26:30Z", "config": {}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls7y9u0m6hk7k", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716162738841, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 2, "folders": ["general_questions"], "nr": 419, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-04T21:10:17Z", "bucket_order": 0, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "data": "ls7zymugbwr1ym", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-04T21:10:17Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "data": "ls80gau0olu2be", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-02-04T21:24:01Z"}], "bucket_name": "Pinned", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "subject": "What is a segfault and why do we care?", "created": "2024-02-04T21:24:01Z", "content": "

It is the time of the year when I post this piazza note. The note is regarding segfault you may have already seen or you will see in the near future.

Most posts these days are about the so called segmentation fault. I want to answer this question in more detail.

A simple ultimate answer to this question: There is a real bug in your code. Segmentation fault is not because of which OS/computer you run.

What is a segmentation fault?

Answer: Your program accessed illegal memory space somewhere, including reading or writing.

Why the segfault is only reported on Linux, not Windows or vice versa?

Answer: segfault is machine-dependent.

I will explain this using an analogy - different pandemic restrictions across the globe. During the time of the pandemic, most of the countries have their own versions of "lockdown" or "stay-at-home order". The basic idea is that you should not go outside for any unessential purpose. That being said, it means going out for an unessential purpose is "illegal". For some of the Asian countries, harsh enforcement takes place. Going out for an unessential purpose may put you in jail time. For North American countries, doing so will face no legal consequence.

Does it make you "legal" in North America if you don't comply with stay-at-home order? No. Not being spotted by the authority does not make the action legal. This is the same as a segfault. Your program may accessed illegal memory on your machine but didn't get caught by the OS, but it is caught by the OS used by ECF. The bug is there no matter if segfault is triggered or not. As long as you see any segfault, that means there is a bug in your code.

Is it serious?

Yes, it is serious. Another analogy I love to use for pointers is the actual room number we use in a condo or a building. Let's imagine the content in your memory as the people living in each room. The keys are the pointers to each room. Dereference operation is equivalent to opening the corresponding door using the key. If you hold a key to some room, does it mean that the room is yours? No, you have to own the room.

So yes, it is serious. If you don't own a room but have the key to that room is dangerous. Image one day, some strangers opened the door to your room, and started replacing your stuff with his own stuff (illegal write to a memory space). 

How can I solve a segmentation fault?

Now we need to find a way to solve this problem. As you may have noticed, most of the posts about segmentation faults are unanswered or take a while before they are answered. This is because segfault is not trivial at all. It can be caused by several possible scenarios, accessing elements out of bound, using a dangling pointer, copying memory to another illegal memory, etc. Solving a segfault needs the understanding of your code. It is not an easy job for other people to read and try to understand your code. Therefore, the best candidate to solve the segfault (you may already guessed) is yourself.

The tool we can use to solve segfault:

1. If you can reproduce segfault in your local machine, great! Use a debugger to identify the line where segfault happens and try to solve it.

2. If you can reproduce segfault on ECF, great! Use a debugger to identify the line where segfault happens and try to solve it.

3. To speedup your debugging, try to use address sanitizer (explained in the follow-up discussion) and see what you can get. (It only works on Linux so not so good...)

4. Go over your code carefully and examine each line where you dereferenced a pointer, this includes "*a"(directly dereference a pointer) or "a[0]"(access an element in an array), or "func(a)"(pass in a pointer to some function).

You should find your bug after step 4.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "subject": "What is a segfault and why do we care?", "created": "2024-02-04T21:10:17Z", "content": "

It is the time of the year when I post this piazza note. The note is regarding segfault you may have already seen or you will see in the near future.

Most posts these days are about the so called segmentation fault. I want to answer this question in more detail.

A simple ultimate answer to this question: There is a real bug in your code. Segmentation fault is not because of Examify.

What is a segmentation fault?

Answer: Your program accessed illegal memory space somewhere, including reading or writing.

Why the segfault is only reported on Linux, not Windows or vice versa?

Answer: segfault is machine-dependent.

I will explain this using an analogy - different pandemic restrictions across the globe. During the time of the pandemic, most of the countries have their own versions of "lockdown" or "stay-at-home order". The basic idea is that you should not go outside for any unessential purpose. That being said, it means going out for an unessential purpose is "illegal". For some of the Asian countries, harsh enforcement takes place. Going out for an unessential purpose may put you in jail time. For North American countries, doing so will face no legal consequence.

Does it make you "legal" in North America if you don't comply with stay-at-home order? No. Not being spotted by the authority does not make the action legal. This is the same as a segfault. Your program may accessed illegal memory on your machine but didn't get caught by the OS, but it is caught by the OS used by ECF. The bug is there no matter if segfault is triggered or not. As long as you see any segfault, that means there is a bug in your code.

Is it serious?

Yes, it is serious. Another analogy I love to use for pointers is the actual room number we use in a condo or a building. Let's imagine the content in your memory as the people living in each room. The keys are the pointers to each room. Dereference operation is equivalent to opening the corresponding door using the key. If you hold a key to some room, does it mean that the room is yours? No, you have to own the room.

So yes, it is serious. If you don't own a room but have the key to that room is dangerous. Image one day, some strangers opened the door to your room, and started replacing your stuff with his own stuff (illegal write to a memory space). 

How can I solve a segmentation fault?

Now we need to find a way to solve this problem. As you may have noticed, most of the posts about segmentation faults are unanswered or take a while before they are answered. This is because segfault is not trivial at all. It can be caused by several possible scenarios, accessing elements out of bound, using a dangling pointer, copying memory to another illegal memory, etc. Solving a segfault needs the understanding of your code. It is not an easy job for other people to read and try to understand your code. Therefore, the best candidate to solve the segfault (you may already guessed) is yourself.

The tool we can use to solve segfault:

1. If you can reproduce segfault in your local machine, great! Use a debugger to identify the line where segfault happens and try to solve it.

2. If you can reproduce segfault on ECF, great! Use a debugger to identify the line where segfault happens and try to solve it.

3. To speedup your debugging, try to use address sanitizer (explained in the follow-up discussion) and see what you can get. (It only works on Linux so not so good...)

4. Go over your code carefully and examine each line where you dereferenced a pointer, this includes "*a"(directly dereference a pointer) or "a[0]"(access an element in an array), or "func(a)"(pass in a pointer to some function).

You should find your bug after step 4.

The address is randomly generated. If you are saying if you declare a variable on stack/heap, will the address follows some pattern then the answer is yes for some cases. Stack allocates memory from top to bottom and heap allocates memory from bottom to top.

For example, you have a code snippet like below,

int a = 0;
int b = 2;

Assume the address of a is 0xFF70 8000. Since an integer has a size of 4 bytes and b is declared on stack, b should have an address of 0xFF70 7FFC.

However, the address on heap may not be continuous if you call malloc() twice. The returned address is not guaranteed to be continuous. // <- Not sure if you have already covered malloc but you will

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-05T21:20:10Z", "content": "

There are separate rules for each kind of variable: global variables follow different rules than variables declared in functions (often called local variables). There are set rules, but depending on your operating system, it will randomize where the addresses start as a security measure.

So the TL:DR answer is, yes, but most of the time the rules start with a random value, so you can't guess. We don't go into the rules in this course.", "created": "2024-02-05T21:23:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Willie Wang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljqautvgbac50w", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "l7peamq9ldd3rp", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["ljqautvgbac50w"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls9fvftdwjq5ho", "updated": "2024-02-10T08:53:15Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls9f08i0ok67lr", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716162745014, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["general_questions"], "nr": 435, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-07T03:17:48Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsb7yz9gv052f5", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-07T03:17:48Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "l7peamq9ldd3rp", "data": "lsb8g3dy9ti2ql", "to": "lsb7yz9921j2f4", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-07T03:31:07Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "to": "lsb7yz9921j2f4", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-07T12:09:42Z", "cid": "lsbqz0djqh21cg"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "textbook 6.3", "created": "2024-02-07T03:17:48Z", "content": "why the function can change the value of a and b? I only return the address of b in this function."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["general_questions", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 45, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-07T03:31:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "l7peamq9ldd3rp", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-07T03:31:07Z", "content": "

Sorry, what do you mean by you only return the address of b?

The program starts running on line 10, creates two variables (a and b) in main. We then create a variable called f and set its value to the address of b.

On line 12: we do a function call to confuse.

confuse gets a copy of the address of a (in main) as argument x, and a copy of the address of b (in main) as the argument y and execution jumps to the confuse function.

On line 3: we dereference y, accessing the value of b (in main), and increment it. The value of b (in main) is now 8.

On line 4: we re-assign the value of y (in confuse) to the value of x. After this line the variable y now has the address of a (in main).

On line 5: we dereference y, accessing the value of a (in main), and set its value to 10. The value of a (in main) is now 10.

On line 6: we return a copy of y, which is the address of a (in main). The we're done running the confusion function, and resume in main.

On line 12: we assign f the value returned from the function. The value of f is now the address of a.

On line 13: we dereference f, accessing the value of a and increment it. The value of a is now 11.

On line 14: we print the values of a and b, currently a is 11 and b is 8.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsb8g3dpz002qj", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

The video embedded in the book explains this further: https://youtu.be/HcZ5TUSpj8E?si=kmMyPgZ2ulFPrbjI
