I have two questions about the starting code posted for lab 5

1. Is the function offer() supposed to be called every time after eliminate_cases()? Because that would results in the "banker" asking for deal after every open of the case(s). Shouldn't it be called after each round rather than after each elimination of the cases?

2. The remove_case_and_get_amount() function takes [int cases_size] as one of the inputs but never used it, so the compiler is displaying a warning saying "unused parameter" or something. What should I do with that?

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Lab 5 question about the starting code", "created": "2024-02-07T05:37:23Z", "content": "

I have two questions about regarding starting code posted for lab 5

1. Is the function offer() supposed to be called every time after eliminate_cases()? Because that would results in the "banker" asking for deal after every open of the case(s). Shouldn't it be called after each round rather than after each elimination of the cases?

2. The remove_case_and_get_amount() function takes [int cases_size] as one of the inputs but never used it, so the compiler is displaying a warning saying "unused parameter" or something. What should I do with that?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 115, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-07T10:48:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "jia yi Xu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljv7m5l01vv4yy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "l7peamq9ldd3rp", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-07T10:48:56Z", "content": "

1. The logic for this is given to you, we call offer only after every round, e.g.

eliminate_cases(cases, cases_size, 6);
offer(cases, cases_size, initial_amount);

2. You can ignore it, you may want to use it to help you debug, or help sanity check.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lab4", "lab5"], "nr": 439, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-09T00:56:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsdxsbdao1e275", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-09T00:56:00Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevc7iza7in11p", "data": "lsdy2ehcvgu24a", "to": "lsdxsbcvl5v274", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-09T01:03:50Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "to": "lsdxsbcvl5v274", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-09T18:49:55Z", "cid": "lsf05drbwer3i3"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "What is an executable file", "created": "2024-02-09T00:56:00Z", "content": "

What is an executable file for lab 4 and 5 in one of the recent announcements, and what purpose does it serve? Why is it optional and is it recommended that I run it? 

Thank you

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab4", "lab5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 99, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-09T01:03:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevc7iza7in11p", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-09T01:03:50Z", "content": "

an executable file very simply stated is your "program" that the computer executes. It basically has some encoded sequence of instructions that the computer can understand provided by your C code. Remember how at the start of the semester, it was taught that computers only understand 0's and 1's (binary)? Well...

#include <stdio.h>

int main(void) {
		printf("Hello World\n);
}

certainly does not look like 0's and 1's but compiling it turns it into a representation your computer can understand.

A simple program like "Hello World" is actually quick complicated underneath the hood (assembly and machine instructions and what not). We are quite lucky to be coding and living in today's world, we stand on the shoulders of giants who could not just type

printf("Hello World");

and have display "Hello World". 

When you run gcc blah blah before every submission, you're generating an executable. 

Compiling a C code -> generating an executable that your computer can understand and execute.

You want to use it because the executable provided is the SOLUTION C code's program.

So you run your exectuable

You run the executable given (what is expected).

Compare the two.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsdy2eh6xnu249", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

Remember when we said in class that when we compile code using gcc, it generates the program in 0's and 1's. These 0's and 1's are what the CPU executes. The file that stores these 0's and 1's is the executable. 

We provided the executable in case you want to test out the how the solution behaves with some inputs. It is optional because we already tell you how it behaves in the lab handouts.

I copied my code to the remote connection without changing anything (I used 42 for seed). When I was testing my code locally, the second test case output the correct value of 3.1374. However, when I ran my code on ECF, my output for case 2 changed to 3.1416. There were no error messages and I used -lm. I could be missing something but I'm not sure what it could be.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Output correct locally but different on ECF", "created": "2024-02-10T15:31:04Z", "content": "

I copied my code to the remote connection without changing anything (I used 42 for seed). When I was testing my code locally, the second test case output the correct value of 3.1374. However, when I ran my code on ECF, my output for case 2 changed to 3.1416. There were no error messages and I used -lm. I could be missing something but I'm not sure what it could be.

I have completed part 2 and it seems that my output is same as the test case. However, it shows an error:

Error: program output contains non ascii characters

I searched through internet and some people say that it might caused by copy and pasting of something that is autoformatted into ASCII. The only part that I copy and paste is the printf part of the lab 5 instruction to minimize any typo mistakes. How can I solve this error?

Screenshot_2024-02-15_at_1.10.14_AM.pngScreenshot_2024-02-15_at_1.10.24_AM.png

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 131, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-15T15:19:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-15T15:19:03Z", "content": "

1- Go to Settings

2- Type Unicode then enter

3- Scroll down and check the following:

Editor: Unicode Highlight: Ambiguous Characters (should be ticked)

Editor: Unicode Highlight: Invisible Characters (should be ticked)

Editor: Unicode Highlight: Non Basic ASCII (should be set to true)

4- Go back to your lab 5, and look for any highlighted characters.

It may look like this. So erase it and retype it.

Hi, for lab 5 should we prevent the user from attempting to eliminate the case they chose (ex. they picked case 1 originally, but then they use enter case 1 to eliminate )?

\n

\n

From my understanding of the game, the next cases the user picks are just to eliminate them, so technically they shouldn't be allowed to eliminate the case they chose, since the only time they can 'swap' is with the last case.

Your atan function is correct, but your output calculation is not, it should be 4*arctan(1/5)-arctan(1/239) (you added an extra factor of 4) -- moreover, the previous formula calculates $$\frac{\pi}{4}$$ not $$\pi$$, so you have to multiply by 4 again.

Question^^^

Hello! 

I just wanted to make sure I'm understanding this solution properly, since I initially mis-interpreted what the question was even asking for and now I'm a bit unsure.

So essentially what we're doing is running the while loop until we get some sort of overflow error, and then praying that the printf statement still runs after the overflow error showing us how many bits are used? If this is correct, does C normally run the rest of the code after an error or does it stop at that line and spit out the error for you to fix?

Thank you for your time!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 82, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-19T01:27:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jia Li", "endorser": {"ljajlq9tev95ta": 1690912136, "global": 1692840759, "lmfq4ih2l7q35f": 1696093075}, "admin": false, "photo": "1691638193_200.jpg", "id": "ljq411p5fwa5il", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/ljq411p5fwa5il/1691638193_200.jpg", "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-19T01:27:05Z", "content": "

The purpose of the program is to determine the number of bits in an int variable (including the sign bit) without using the sizeof operator.

The solution works by creating an integer k with only one bit equal to 1, then moves it to the left (towards more significant digits) until the integer becomes negative. Since all negative integers have a bit set in the most significant position and there is only one bit set, we know that the bit has arrived at the end of the integer. We can therefore calculate the number of bits by counting the number of iterations required to do this.

It is an overflow error, but even though we use the word error to describe it, this is not an invalid operation (it's not even considered abnormal on the CPU). Thus the CPU reports no error and the program does not stop (you are right that a CPU error will stop the program however).

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 55, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-19T17:00:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Ibraheem El Sheikha", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljt5iipa6ok28u", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Sara Shaur", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lly6c9qn4nu287", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-19T17:11:25Z", "content": "

Note that when using the modulo operator with positive integers, the result of num % n ranges from 0 to n - 1, as long as n is not equal to 0.

So when you do rand() % 334, the range of possible numbers is from 0 to 333. To put them in the range of 666 to 999, you can add 666 to the result.

The division by 10 then puts them in the range of 66.6 to 99.9.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-19T17:07:19Z", "content": "

Note that when taking the modulus of a positive number, the result is always is either from 0 to one less that number (num % n ranges from 0 to n - 1, as long as n is not equal to 0).

So when you do rand() % 334, the range of possible numbers is from 0 to 333. To put them in the range of 666 to 999, you can add 666 to the result.

The division by 10 then puts them in the range of 66.6 to 99.9.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-19T17:03:17Z", "content": "

The division by 10 then puts them in the range of 66.6 to 99.9.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-19T17:00:41Z", "content": "

Note that when taking the modulus of a number (when that number is not equal to 0), the result is always is either from 0 to one less that number (num % n ranges from 0 to n - 1).

So when you do rand() % 334, the range of possible numbers is from 0 to 333. To put them in the range of 666 to 999, you can add 666 to the result.

The division by 10 then puts them in the range of 66.6 to 99.9.

We will use reverse engineering. We know we can't generate real numbers (numbers with decimals using rand()), so we will generate numbers between 666 and 999 then divide by 10.0.

It's easy from here, we use the formula discussed in class. rand() generates a number between 0 and 2^31 - 1. If we do % (999 - 666 + 1), we get a number between 0 and (999 - 666). Adding to that 666, gives us a number between 666 and 999. Divide that by 10.0, and that gives you a number between 66.6 and 99.9.

I could be wrong here, but to my understanding there is a subtle difference between modulo and remainder that only comes into play for negative numbers. The "modulo" operator in c simply returns the remainder from division, which in the case of $$-6/18$$, is just going to be $$-6$$. That being said, this result differs from modulo (in a mathematical context) which will always give the same sign as the divisor and is defined with the equation you showed in the question

EDIT: I just found this, it might help c - What's the difference between “mod” and “remainder”? - Stack Overflow

The "modulo" operator in c simply returns the remainder from division, which in the case of $$-6/18$$, is just going to be $$-6$$. That being said, this result differs from modulo (in a mathematical context) which will always give the same sign as the divisor. "}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukgfqdy6208"], "children": [], "id": "lsti0ntsj7v62z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

hi all, might be silly but I had this debate with classmates in elementary school while doing actual word searches so here goes:

lab 6 instructions state that: "Searching for the word should happen in all directions. There are 8 directions: south-
east, south, south-west, west, north-west, north, north-east and east."

does this mean that the word can be spelled diagonally, backwards, diagonal and backwords, etc.?

so say if we were looking for the word "cat", would any of these count?

1. tac (backwords)

2. c

      a

        t  (diagonal)

3. t

     a

       c ( backwords and diagonal)

4. t

    a

    c    (backwords, down)

5.    c

   a

t        (backwords, diagonally up)

6.    t

   a

c        (diagonally up)


I'm sure there are many other combos, but just knowing if I need to consider these initial ones would help me get started on the function.

Hi, for question 4 of midterm 2023, how does *p have the value of myArray[5] and not 0 in another [5]? Will it be possible to explain how *p works?

Also, having p = myArray does it mean that myArray will always start at 0 and p has the index value or it has another meaning?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 49, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-20T18:53:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukirceh427b", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-20T19:04:31Z", "content": "

I'm not exactly sure what you're asking but I can explain how pointers work with arrays and hopefully that can help.

Arrays and pointers are pretty similar in that the array identifier is a pointer to the first element of that array. In other words, when you create an array "int arr[5];", "arr" is the same thing as "&arr[0]". Thats why you can intialize a pointer "int *p;" and set them equal. "p = arr". This is the same as making p point to the first element of the array.

On the other hand, "p - arr" takes the address held in p, subtracts it from the address held in arr (&arr[0]), then divides by the size of the elements of the array (in the case of integers, it divides by 4 for the 4 bytes). It basically gives the distance between the addresses held in p and arr, so the division by 4 bytes is necessary to compensate for the fact that integers are represented with 4 bytes

Not sure how good I explained that so heres the textbook chapter for a better explanation haha 7.2. What are arrays, and how are they stored? — Snefru: Learning Programming with C (learningc.org)

If we dereference p using *p, then we are accessing the element in the array. For example, *p if p stored &myArray[1], then we are accessing myArray[1] which is 4. Please follow up with questions if you need further clarification."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsur7qs8ooa3uu", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

", "created": "2024-02-20T19:44:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Initially p is myArray, which is in other terms p is &myArray[0]. In `another[p - myArray] = *p;`, if p is myArray, then `p - myArray` is `&myArray[0] - &myArray[0]` which is 0. This translates to `another[0] = *(&myArray[0]);` so another[0] is set to 2. In the next iteration, we increment p by `p++` so p is now `&myArray[0] + 1` which is `&myArray[1]`. In `another[p - myArray] = *p;`, `p - myArray` is `&myArray[1] - &myArray[0]`, which is 1 and *p is *(&myArray[1]) which is `myArray[1]`. Just to make sure I understand clearly this part: is &myArray[1] - &myArray [0] = 1 because this equation is equal to (&myArray[0] + 1) - (&myArray[0]) so &myArray[0] cancel out and we are left with 1.

The same thing is happening in the fifth iteration where:

 p = &myArray[4]:

-> another[p - myArray] = *p;

-> where: [p-myArray] is &myArray[4] - &myArray[0]

which is (&myArray[0] + 4) - (&myarray[0]), which is 4.

*p is *(&myArray[4]) which is myArray[4]. 

We get: another[4] = myArray[4]

Just to clarify, I'm not entirely sure about this answer so please feel free to edit it.

From what the professor put as a description of the task, I noticed dynamic arrays and dynamic management too. 

I'm not as experienced in coding but my guess is that because these concepts deal with memory leaks and writing memory dynamically that there could be mismanagement of memory and that could be a potential area for testing too, so that's what my guess is, for the reason that the lab doesn't show it, so that it can be implicitly tested for the extra hidden test cases or marks.

However, after some research, I also learnt that we can do the checks ourselves through:
valgrind --leak-check=full ./lab6.c

so technically we can do it ourselves to confirm and because of the dynamic nature of memory management, it might be implicitly marked.

The question asks to provide an implementation of a function called findMaximumValue that finds the max value of an array, and if the max is negative or 0, it returns 0. In the solution however, there is no code that ensures any max values that are negative, result in 0 being returned(below). 

should the following code have to be implemented:

if (maximumValue<=0)

   return 0;

else

   return maximumValue;

or is the solution correct?

I understand where your struggle comes from so I'll just explain what my professor does since that breaks down your question about why there's a loop for the rows first then for the columns.

Follow these steps: 

1. Draw out the stars and spaces in a table, literally a table.

2. Label the rows and columns of the table, let me show you in this example here: 

01234
1**
2**
3**
4**

3. Identify the relationship between the rows and and columns - to do this, you need to basically see how the number for the row relates to the number for the column.

For example, the first row has a star in column 1 and 4

Second row in column 2 and 3

Third row in column 3 and 2

Fourth row in column 4 and 1 

4. Draw this out in another table to see how rows and columns relate, look at this example here:

RowColumn 1Column 2
114
223
332
441

Ah and now you see a patten :)

So you create a loop for the rows first because you see that the rows in the table increase from 1 - 4 going downward, so its logically easier, please don't memorize that, approach it with logic.

5. Okay so now we've seen a pattern which is convenient, let's just make a loop that follows those patterns in our table, which is where our logic comes into play and we code it directly, with the approach you mentioned for having a loop for the rows first and now having a loop for the columns based on what you saw on the table above.

6. So the approach is to print spaces and then print stars in the cases we identified in the table above :)

I hope that helped.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-21T01:39:35Z", "content": "

when i took this course 3 years ago...

i usually broke it down into

for loop for the num of rows:
      for loop for the outer leading spaces: //comment 1
           print blanks here
       print a star here
       for loop for the inner spaces: //comment 2
           print blanks here
       print a star here
       for loop for the outer trailing spaces //comment 3
           print blanks here
        print new line here for rows
        
       //Note, comments 1, 2, 3 usually depends on number of rows or the index that goes up to number of rows

General skeleton above but it worked for me for most questions. But obviously some patterns may be a lot different.

Generally, I like to try and break it up into rows, spaces, stars and use diff for loops for each thing.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 538, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-21T19:51:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsw7mg0u232515", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-21T19:51:13Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "data": "lsw821ms7gn3gw", "to": "lsw7mg0jsc5513", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-21T20:03:21Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Midterm 2023 Q6", "created": "2024-02-21T19:51:13Z", "content": "

Hi, for Question 6 of midterm 2023, I'm a bit confused why the value at a remains the same and isn't the same as b.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "John Kim", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk42eyeqsz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 61, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-21T20:03:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Chizaram Amobi-Oleka", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljltcjb8xa5408", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-21T20:03:21Z", "content": "

Halfway through the modify function, a is changed such that it points to b. So when you run the line *a = *a + 5, it's the same thing as running *b = *b + 5. Therefore, the value at a won't be changed.

If you want a step-by-step break through of the question, Professor Eyolfson covered it in one of his midterm review lectures: https://youtu.be/iJRAmaSpj7k?t=1554

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ljltcjb8xa5408"], "children": [], "id": "lsw821mlic13gv", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7uk42eyeqsz"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsw7mg0jsc5513", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 1, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716162862488, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 539, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-21T19:52:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsw7oemrmbq12v", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-21T19:52:45Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "data": "lsw8mq7iy0r74t", "to": "lsw7oemjyjw12t", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-21T20:19:26Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "2014 Midterm Question 14", "created": "2024-02-21T19:52:45Z", "content": "

I'm having trouble understanding the logic behind this question. If someone could explain the logic for the highlighted part it would be greatly appreciated :) Also, can we use an array of the letters (as in array[26]) and use nested loops to print elements from the array to solve the question?

piazza.jpg

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 44, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-21T20:19:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Gauri Karajagi", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l79f18dabuv1qm", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-21T20:19:26Z", "content": "

Note the pattern, as you go to 1 place to the right, you print the next character. If you go to 1 place to the bottom, you print the next character.

For example, if you go 1 place to the bottom right (diagonally), you can think as 1 place to the right and 1 place to the bottom. Therefore, you would print the next next character.

That is equivalent as saying there is some relationship between (i+j) and the character you would like to print.

The modulo operation is to make sure the character will wrap back.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["l79f18dabuv1qm"], "children": [], "id": "lsw8mq7b91774s", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsw7oemjyjw12t", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716162863517, "default_anonymity": "no"}

", "created": "2024-02-21T20:16:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Toon Craps", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1700667274}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukr1754d2wl"], "id": "lsw8ietd6kp5xo", "updated": "2024-02-21T20:17:04Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsw8ccthnoj524", "updated": "2024-02-21T20:18:15Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Using i++ does two things:
FIRST return the value of i
then increment i by 1

Using ++i does the reverse:
FIRST increment i by 1
then return the value of i

When we use
printf(“%d”, i++);
we first return the value of i (which is 0)
-> that value is printed
then, we increment i by 1

so, when we print i in the next line, its updated value (which is 1) is printed.

If the array identifier is a pointer to the first element of the array, then why does sizeof(arr) not return the size of the pointer?

Running this prints 20 and 8, so I'm guessing that the 20 comes from the size of the entire array (5 elements x 4 bytes per element), and the pointer to the first element of the array yields 8 as expected. To my understanding, if arr is a pointer, shouldn't it also print 8? 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["general_questions", "midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 60, "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

The answer is that array is weird in C. Yes, array is a pointer but not quite the same as a regular pointer. You can think of the array as an alias(or a label in a more formal terminology) to the address of the first element of the array. The array as a pointer (the address of itself) doesn't really stored anywhere in the memory space, unlike other regular pointers. Try to print the address of the array and you will find the address of the array is the address of the first element. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 544, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-21T21:48:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lswbtdpoxj21v", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-21T21:48:35Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "data": "lswc73h4tvodc", "to": "lswbtdpgux21u", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-21T21:59:15Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lswbtdpgux21u", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-21T23:15:36Z", "cid": "lswexadfci1498", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lswbtdpgux21u", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-22T00:05:02Z", "cid": "lswgougqsv6n6", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "to": "lswbtdpgux21u", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-26T04:16:40Z", "cid": "lt2ffut5rju11m"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Midterm marking question.", "created": "2024-02-21T21:48:35Z", "content": "For the midterm, if a student’s solution is not identical to the faculty solution, how will it be marked? 

Also, how are part marks given? 
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jason Wang", "endorser": {"lr1jp5yrvb87hx": 1707368062, "lrcmycfm19c1g0": 1707692546, "lq1r9f49qpr3p": 1708530924, "global": 1708915880}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukirceh427b", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 93, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-21T21:59:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Deena Abrari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukrjw9d22xr", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-21T21:59:15Z", "content": "

If your code works, full mark.

If not, your answer will be marked accordingly. It is different from questions to questions.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukrjw9d22xr"], "children": [], "id": "lswc73gwqhudb", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Sorry, one more thing. 

If our program does something not allowed in C (like trying to modulo two double variables), will our entire solution be marked as 0, or will it still be marked in some form?
", "created": "2024-02-21T23:15:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

(feel free to edit) 

Talked to my professor about this and he said that the marking is not based directly on the output or fully matching the solutions (given that these 2 are not already done).

He mentioned that the goal of the course is for us to understand the logic behind coding and not memorize, which means that fundamentally, your program will be marked based on how you logically approached it, which makes me certain that the marking TAs will definitely cut a mark for potential illegal errors, but that doesn't give them the right to mark your entire answer as 0, because that defeats the purpose of the course and forces memorization, it'll instead be based on logic.

Also to add on to that, as you're revising for the mid-term, don't memorize, understand the logic, because that's what programming is, fundamentally :)

Sizeof(myarray)

Where myarray is the pointer to a one-dimensional non-dynamically allocated array in main.
Does sizeof() return the size of the pointer, or the size of the array? 

Also, are there any exceptions to how sizeof() works that aren’t immediately obvious? 


I used it in a solution to Q8 of the 2023 midterm here: 

IMG_5949_2024_02_21.jpeg

@543

However, with srand it is constrained to one seed but the one seed contains multiple numbers that it can use. Is this a correct understanding?", "created": "2024-04-25T21:31:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_2", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lvfreeb5t142dg", "updated": "2024-04-25T21:31:52Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

There is a slight misunderstanding with the explanation above, the seed does not increment every time you call rand(). The seed basically holds a sequence of "random" numbers (see image below for an example, taken from the textbook).

Every time you call rand() it will use the next random number in the sequence. If you use srand(), you'll be using a different sequence of numbers.

Note that for each time you run your program, it will start from the first number in the seed.

This section of the textbook discusses random numbers in-depth: https://learningc.org/chapters/chapter02-variables/random-number

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 549, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-22T18:24:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsxjypbluax5c3", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-22T18:24:27Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lsxkib7h7j4416", "to": "lsxjypbcio15c2", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-22T18:39:41Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lsxjypbcio15c2", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-22T18:45:47Z", "cid": "lsxkq5g8iw21k9", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "to": "lsxjypbcio15c2", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-22T18:46:45Z", "cid": "lsxkre4an181q2"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Generating random numbers between MAX and MIN", "created": "2024-02-22T18:24:27Z", "content": "Why is the formula to generate random numbers between max and min this:
rand()%(max-min+1) + min?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nithura Thevarajah", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk96a8bm1dp", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 56, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-22T18:39:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Lucas Wolfgang Ahn", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljww2wwy5x05wq", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-22T18:39:41Z", "content": "

The unmodified rand() function generates an integer between 0 and a constant (RAND_MAX) inclusive (for the sake of argument I'm assuming that RAND_MAX equals 100).

When we take the modulo $$n$$ of a number $$x$$, we calculate its residue under $$n$$ (see this article for details). In practice, this means mapping every integer to a number in the set $$\left\{0,1,\ldots,n-1\right\}$$, which has $$n$$ elements. Thus when we take rand() % n we map all of its possible outputs to a set of only $$n$$ possibilities.

The formula rand() % (max-min+1) + min is thus mapping the output of the rand() function to a set of values such that there are the same number of values as there are numbers between max and min inclusive, and then shifting everything up by min (recall that the smallest value is $$0$$) so that it has the image we want.

I believe it's saying that the size of the array can be stored in an integer variable, for example, int size = 10; or const int size = 10;

It is saying that the length should be stored in an integer, that way it can be passed to functions. For example, if you have int arr[] = {1, 2, 3}, then you would want to store the size of the array in a variable like int or int const = 3. Or you could also do #define 

In the C language, you can't use a variable to declare the size of an array: you have to use a literal value. That is, a statement like int t=1; int tab[t]; is invalid, but int tab[10]; is acceptable. If you are curious as to why, it's because arrays need to have a known compile-time size in C (i.e. a literal), but a variable, even a const, is stored somewhere in memory, which is not usable for fixed size allocation.

Whenever I make my conditions >= it wont fill the rest of my inner pyramid. Instead it will go crazy.

int main(void) {
  int lines=6;
  printf("Input number of lines: ");
  scanf("%d", &lines);

  // rows
  for (int row = 1; row <= lines; row++) {
    for(int col = 1; col<=(2*lines)-1;col++){
      if(col == lines||(col+row)==(lines+1)||(col-row)== lines -1){
        printf("*");

      } else {
        printf(" ");
      }
    }
    printf("\n");

  }

  return 0;
}
This is when it goes crazy.

What is the certain bound.", "created": "2024-02-22T21:38:16Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lsxqvylsg2k2pm", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-02-22T21:38:16Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

That depends, col=1 row=1 not always have a star

You can try to go over some detailed example to find a pattern.

When row = 0,

0th row has a bound of 0 to 0

When row = 1,

0th row has a bound of 1 to 1

1st row has a bound of 0 to 2

When row = 2,

0th row has a bound of 2 to 2 (start bound = row - i = 2 - 0 = 2, end bound = row + i = 2 + 0 = 0)

1st row has a bound of 1 to 3 (start bound = row - i, end bound = row + i)

2nd row has a bound of 0 to 4 (start bound = row - i, end bound = row + i)

...

For each row, you can find pattern: start bound = row - i, end bound = row + i

To clarify on the discussion below, your bounds are (col+row)==(lines+1) (lower bound?) and (col-row)== lines -1 (upper bound?) part of the condition. You also have col == lines .

I would write it as print star if ( col==lines±(row-1) ) so that you have col as a clear "independent variable" and clear bounds - the minus of the plus-minus is and lower bound, and the positive is the upper bound. 

You can combine all three of the above conditions into an inclusive range like so: print star if ( col >= lines - (row-1) && col <= lines + (row-1) ). This way you also don't have to include the condition col == lines because it's already in range.

If you try with inequalities using the condition above, it doesn't work as intended: 

 

though the inverted triangle is interesting 

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-23T19:36:43Z", "content": "

To clarify on the discussion below, your bounds are (col+row)==(lines+1) (lower bound?) and (col-row)== lines -1 (upper bound?) part of the condition. You also have col == lines .

I would write it as print star if ( col==lines±(row-1) ) so that you have col as a clear "independent variable" and clear bounds - the minus of the plus-minus is and lower bound, and the positive is the upper bound. 

You can combine all three of the above conditions into an inclusive range like so: print star if ( col >= lines - (row-1) && col <= lines + (row-1) ). This way you also don't have to include the condition col == lines because it's already in range.

If you try with inequalities using the condition above, it doesn't work as intended: 

though the inverted triangle is interesting

Assume you have a variable X stored in memory address MEM1. When you pass X to a function, a new copy of X is created in MEM2 and this is what's passed to the function. Any changes made to X within the function are applied to MEM2, not MEM1. That's why when you return from the function, the value in MEM1 remains unchanged.

\n

\n

Now, assume you have a pointer P which stores the address MEM1 (MEM1 stores the value of X). P itself must be stored in an address, say MEM_P1. When P is passed to a function, a new copy of that pointer is created in MEM_P2 (this new copy still stores MEM1) and is passed to the function. Within the function, you can dereference the pointer (access the value in the memory address which is stored in the pointer) and make changes to it. This means that any change is done to the value stored in MEM1, which is the same original memory address storing the value of X. So, when you return from that function, the changes done to the variable stored in MEM1 are retained.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsyuknyc991cs", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsytwlsmgfc2um", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716162882077, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Hello,

Can someone explain the logic behind this block of code (for the solution to q11, 2019 exam). I understand that you are now setting all negative values in the array to 0, but what does it mean if "index i was over-written" and shrink the array?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 53, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-23T16:25:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Hanna Bui", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul3hccbr41t", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Manahil Saeed", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm562039i1l1bg", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Suzen Bao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukh5cyqz224", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukirceh427b", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-23T16:40:59Z", "content": "

When they shifted the later values of the array forward, it overwrites the value at index i. Looking at the loop just above the screenshot in the question, you can see it starts at int j = i;, and the loop moves each value following the one at i forward by one place. We must then decrement i to recheck whether or not the value immediately following the removed negative is also negative, since it would be skipped otherwise. 

Then array[size - 1] = 0 takes the final value in the array and makes it zero. This is equivalent to moving the negative to the back and deleting it, since we moved all the values behind the negative forward. If we did not do this, then the value at the end of the array at the start of the loop would remain there. 

Note that we aren't really "deleting" or "shrinking" anything. Like I said above, the "delete" is really just "make the last number 0 since we moved all other values forward" and "shrink" is really just "don't touch any of the 0s we've already placed" 

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukirceh427b", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-23T16:25:42Z", "content": "

When you subtract two pointers of the same type, the result is the difference between their addresses divided by the size of the data type. In this case, q = &x[2] = 24 (address of the third element of x) and x also points to its first element (&x[0] = 16). (The addresses 24 and 16 are arbitrary).

When you subtract the two pointers, you first subtract their addresses (24 - 16 = 8) and then divide by their data type size (sizeof(int) = 4, 8 / 4 = 2). This makes sense, since x[2] is two elements away from x[0].

Also, just to add on, an important thing that I sometimes forget is like when my classmate mentions "q = &x[2] = 24 ", how is this the third address when it says 2? So the answer to that is because it starts from 0, so its 0, 1, 2 and that's why its the third address, here I used to get confused, so be sure to remember that you start at zero, not at one.

Why? I’ve been trying to rationalize it to myself mathematically, but was not successful yet. 
 
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 40, "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "% returns the remainder of division. (I'll assume you know modular arithmetic for the following answer)

We consider only non-negative integers ($$\mathbb{Z}_{\ge 0}$$) since rand() only produces outputs in this set. The modulo operator is equivalent to computing a number's residue. For example, 3 % 5 in C is equivalent to $$(3\!\!\mod5)$$. When working mod $$n$$, there are exactly $$n$$ residue classes and hence $$n$$ unique (when taking the least residue set) residues. These form a set $$\left\{0,1,\ldots,n-1\right\}$$.

There is a slight error in your formula, it should be (rand() % (A-B+1)) + B) for the interval $$[B,A]$$. Adding $$B$$ "shifts" the numbers so that $$0$$ maps to $$B$$; $$1$$ maps to $$B+1$$ and so on. Moreover since the greatest possible residue is now $$A-B$$ this mapping will make the largest possible value $$A$$.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-24T00:00:18Z", "content": "

Hey, I was practicing with past midterms and I sometimes found myself forgetting to include components of the code until later. In these cases, during the midterm, could include an arrow on the side with the code that should be included there, or would I need to erase everything that I've written and rewrite it so that it seems like a code that you would see on a computer?

I know that C is not necessarily picky with the format such that I can write an entire program on one line, but for instance if I forgot to include like an if statement, which it'll be hard to include all in one line, could I write it down on the side and draw an arrow to where it should be?

Thanks.

I have been playing around with operations that include both integers and doubles, and then assigning the result to a double, to try to understand how C prioritizes variable types. At first I thought as long as there was a double somewhere in the equation, all the integers would become doubles, but that does not seem to be the case here. Could someone explain how operations with integers and doubles work?

\n

\n

Hi!

For the last part in 2020 Q4, I kind of understand why it gives 3 as final answer:

The outer variable i is declared at the very beginning and the statement "int = 1" in the for loop is kind of like using a new variable instead of i to complete the loop. So the outer i remains unchanged and the program prints 3 as output.

My questions are:

1. How does this code exactly work?

2. Is it legal to use the same variable name in the loop, since i has already been declared outside the loop and the variable name i has already been used. If we redefining i when initializing the loop, why won't it cause an error as the code shown below?

Thank you!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 49, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-24T12:55:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukirceh427b", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-24T12:55:11Z", "content": "I could be wrong here so feel free to edit but your understanding for why the program prints 3 is correct. If you declare a variable inside it with the same name as another variable outside the loop, it is acceptable. This is what we referred to as "overlapping scope." However, if in the same scope you decide to declare a variable with the same name as you are doing in lines 3 and 4 of your screenshot, that is clearly a mistake. This is because you are in the same scope, and you are creating two variables with the same name. What does offsetting the pointer mean and how do you do it exactly?", "created": "2024-02-24T23:29:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

I recommend that you read the section on pointer arithmetic here: 7.2. What are arrays, and how are they stored? — Snefru: Learning Programming with C (learningc.org). As a brief explanation, suppose we have an array 

int arr[] = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};

The array identifier (arr) is also a pointer to the first element of the array. That is, arr is equivalent to &arr[0]. We can do arithmetic on the array identifier. For example, arr + 1 will take the pointer holding the address to the first element of the array, and add 1 * sizeof(int) to it. Since arrays are stored contiguously in memory, moving the pointer by sizeof(int) (4) bytes, will get us to the next element in the array. In other words, arr + 1 is equivalent to &arr[1].  In general, arr + i is equivalent to shifting the pointer to the first element, by i * sizeof(<data type>) where <data type> is the data type that arr stores. 

", "created": "2024-02-24T23:34:56Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lm7ukirceh427b", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lt0pxoww7du3hn", "updated": "2024-02-24T23:34:56Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Actually put more simply, arr + i is equivalent to &arr[i]. "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 50, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-24T16:09:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Salma Emara", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": "1675320204_200.jpg", "id": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/jlzv60dhucu1fm/1675320204_200.jpg", "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukirceh427b", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-24T16:16:37Z", "content": "

First declare an array of 1000 integers that are randomly generated between 0 and 255 inclusive. This array must have repeated instances of certain numbers, and if rand() is "good", this distribution should be somewhat even, that is, each number "randomly" appears at around the same frequency. The problem is asking you to find the number of instances that a certain number appears in the 1000 integer array. 

For example, simplifying to an array of 10 values ranging randomly from 0 to 3, the array might look something like:

int arr[] = {1, 3, 0, 2, 3, 1, 0, 2, 1, 1}; 

The idea is to then create an array of length 4 (number of elements in the random range), whos ith index corresponds to the number of times i appears in the random array. So, that array would look like

int hist[] = {2, 4, 2, 2}; 

Since the 0th entry of hist corresponds to the number of times 0 appears in arr, and so on.

First declare an array of 1000 integers that are randomly generated between 0 and 255 inclusive. This array must have repeated instances of certain numbers, and if rand() is "good", this distribution should be somewhat even, that is, each number "randomly" appears at around the same frequency. The problem is asking you to find the number of instances that a certain number appears in the 1000 integer array. 

For example, simplifying to an array of 10 values ranging randomly from 0 to 3, the array might look something like:

int arr[] = {1, 3, 0, 2, 3, 1, 0, 2, 1, 1}; 

The idea is to then create an array of length 4, whos ith index corresponds to the number of times i appears in the random array. So, that array would look like

int hist[] = {2, 4, 2, 2}; 

Since the 0th entry of hist corresponds to the number of times 0 appears in arr, and so on.

The requestAge() function has an integer pointer has a parameter, so to access the value of the age variable, it needs to dereference it (using *age).

To get the address of a variable, you use the ampersand symbol. In this case, to pass a pointer to age to requestAge(), you do &age.

Also, how do they behave as we run a program? 
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 68, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-24T22:33:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Salma Emara", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": "1675320204_200.jpg", "id": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/jlzv60dhucu1fm/1675320204_200.jpg", "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukirceh427b", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-25T00:41:22Z", "content": "

I think we will learn this when we get to dynamic memory allocation, but I believe the main parts are the application memory and specifically the stack and heap.

The stack holds local variables and is of fixed size. Each time a new function is called, it along with what it contains in its local scope is placed on the stack. Since the stack is finite, it is possible to run out of space on it through too many function calls or large chunks of memory being allocated, thus we can use the heap which is dynamic (but still finite) and acts sort of like a memory pool. We can allocate and deallocate memory on the heap using malloc and free, and we store pointers to addresses of the heap on the stack. This lets us communicate between the fixed memory we have access to on the stack, and the pool of memory available in the heap. 

Hope this helps! And once again I think this is all talked about in the coming lectures 

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukirceh427b", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-24T22:33:15Z", "content": "

I think we will learn this when we get to dynamic memory allocation, but I believe the main parts are the application memory and specifically the stack and heap.

The stack holds local variables and is of fixed size. Each time a new function is called, it along with what it contains in its local scope is placed on the stack. Since the stack is finite, it is possible to run out of space on it through too many function calls or large chunks of memory being allocated, thus we can use the heap which is dynamic and acts sort of like a memory pool. We can allocate and deallocate memory on the heap using malloc and free, and we store pointers to addresses of the heap on the stack. This lets us communicate between the fixed memory we have access to on the stack, and the pool of memory available in the heap. 

Hope this helps! And once again I think this is all talked about in the coming lectures

can an instructor confirm if for the question below, the alternative code I've used that's different from the answer key works (is it something that could get full marks, any noticeable loop holes in logic)? I've basically used the logic that since the variable maxRange is int, and it is given that we can assume  it is greater than 1, then the smallest value that can be inputted is 2. Using that, I've made a separate case for that since the only prime number within the range 1-2 that is a whole number is 2. Otherwise, the code works for every other number as when I input 15, for example, I get 13, and when 14 is input, I get 5. 

Question:

Write a C program that returns a randomly generated prime number between 1 and a maximum int-type integer, maxRange (inclusive), which is provided by the user as input, and is assumed to be greater than 1. A prime number is a natural number greater than 1 that cannot be formed by multiplying two smaller natural numbers. For example, 2, 3, 5, 11, and 13 are all prime numbers.

The program prompts the user “Enter the maximum range: ” to enter the maxRange value and prints “Random prime number generated is ” followed by the randomly generated prime number. You can assume that the user always enters a positive integer greater than 1. You are not allowed to use arrays or pointer variables in your implementation. For convenience, you do not need to seed the random number generator.

my code (for this question):

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>

int main(){
int y=0, maxRange;
int x;
printf ("Enter the maximum range: ");
scanf ("%d", &maxRange);
y = rand() % maxRange + 1;

do{
    if (maxRange == 2){
    printf ("%d \n", maxRange);
    return 0;
    }
    else{
    y = rand() % maxRange + 1;
    }
}while (y%2 == 0);
printf ("Random prime number generated is %d", y);
return 0;
}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 597, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-25T01:55:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lt0uyambb236i", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-25T01:55:22Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "data": "lt2ceegeiur1v2", "to": "lt0uyam3swo36h", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-26T02:51:33Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Assumption for "strength" of comparison statement", "created": "2024-02-25T01:55:22Z", "content": "

For this question in the quiz section of the textbook, some of the answers were marked as "weak" and therefore incorrect because they also work when the rectangles are positioned away from each other, however, the question does not specify that the statement needs to only be true when the rectangles overlap. Would this be something that would be specified on an evaluation, or are we supposed to assume this?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 46, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-26T02:51:33Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-26T02:51:33Z", "content": "

The question expected the condition to be true only when the rectangles overlap (and false otherwise). 

If it were to appear in an exam, the question will clearly state that it's "only" when rectangles overlap. For that sake, I have clarified the question in the book. It will take a minute or so to appear.

"stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "2023 Midterm, would like some clarification on this:", "created": "2024-02-25T03:17:39Z", "content": "

In the solution, they stated for the second printf statement, *a = -5 and *b = 12. I personally ended up with *a = 17 and *b = 17. 

Here is my thought process after the first if-statement: 

*a = -5, *b = 7, and c = 3
a = b; //a now points to address of b 
*a = *a + 5; //a->b=7, since a points to b, and b has value 7. We are doing *a = 7+5
//At this time *a = 12, *b = 12, c = 3, since changing *a will change *b since they share pointees

Then after returning pointer b, a=12 and b=12 c=3. 

Slightly confused here! 

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "2023 Midterm, would like some clarification on this:", "created": "2024-02-25T03:00:07Z", "content": "

In the solution, they stated for the second printf statement, *a = -5 and *b = 12. I personally ended up with *a = 17 and *b = 17. 

Here is my thought process after the first if-statement: 

*a = -5, *b = 7, and c = 3
a = b; //a now points to address of b 
*a = *a + 5; //a->b=7, since a points to b, and b has value 7. We are doing *a = 7+5

When the modify function was called, the address to a and b (in main) was passed, so a and b (in modify) points to a and b (in main), respectively. When a = b is run, a (in modify) points to b (in main), and no longer points to the value of a (in main). So at this point, none of the variables in the modify function point to a (in main).

If you use *a in the modify function before the line a = b, it will return the value of a (in main). However, if you run it after a = b, you will get the value of b (in main).

The value of a is never changed to 12 in the program.

Hi, can someone explain the logic of the inner loop of midterm 2019 question 12? I am not sure to understand how to get the pattern to calculate row #7 of Pascal's triangle.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 78, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-25T18:09:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-02T00:34:31Z", "content": "

So there are two key variables that move together that allow us to compute the nth row, those being saveElement and oneToLeft.

We start oneToLeft at 0 which makes sense since the first entry of any row is going to be 1 (pArray[0] + oneToLeft = 1 + 0 = 1). Then for every subsequent element (call it i), pArray[i] is is updated to pArray[i] + pArray[i - 1], however pArray[i - 1] is not the element we can use in this case, since it was changed in the previous iteration. To compensate for this, we need to maintain the value of pArray[i - 1] before it is updated on the prior iteration. We maintain this value by updating oneToLeft to saveElement, and saveElement is the value of pArray[i - 1] before it is updated. 

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukirceh427b", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-25T18:09:43Z", "content": "

We maintain this value by updating oneToLeft to saveElement, and saveElement is the value of pArray[i - 1] before it is updated.

break does not cause unexpected behaviour if used more than once. It always does what it’s suppose to do… break out of the current loop. 
It’s not like accessing illegal memory which causes unexpected behaviour. 

The reason break is not liked is if you have numerous amount of break statements throughout your loop, it leads to multiple exit points within a loop which can be confusing. This trend is usually found for beginner coding courses (spamming break and continue whenever they can)

Having a couple here and there as “pre checks” is not bad practice and seen throughout industry.

Right but your input will for example be an integer or a character. Aren't we assigning that input to the address of the variable when we use &?

", "created": "2024-02-26T00:18:55Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

We do often use the & symbol when we initialize pointers. For instance,

int a = 5;

int *p = &a;

the second line reads like "p points to the address of a".

If we wanted to use scanf to assign a new value to a, we can use

scanf("%d", &a);

or, equivalently

scanf("%d", p);

because "p points to the address of a".

Hope this provides some insight.

Could ->> int tens = (num%100)/10; also work?

where num is the number we are trying to find the tens digit for?", "created": "2024-04-28T19:20:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Trying it out with different numbers, we get:

num = 5:

  • int tens = 5 % 100 / 10 = 5 / 10 = 0
  • The tens digit is 0, which is correct

num = 67

  • int tens = 67 % 100 / 10 = 67 / 10 = 6
  • The tens digit is 6, so it's also correct

num = 478

  • int tens = 478 % 100 / 10 = 78 / 10 = 7
  • The tens digit is 7, which is also correct.

Your approach to finding the tens digit also works!

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 620, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-26T07:29:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lt2mbs294pf77j", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-26T07:29:27Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lt2ycs74ug21qc", "to": "lt2mbs21p1p77i", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-26T13:06:09Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lt2yecer4383b6", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-02-26T13:07:22Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "data": "lt9cx7tlkb17bi", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-02T00:40:34Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "2020 Midterm Q7 Question", "created": "2024-02-26T07:29:27Z", "content": "

Hi, I am confused by the solution for the question itself. How does the k value track the bit it is on? How does the while loop know when to stop? Won't this function just continuously go on forever since k starts off as 1 and is only multiplied by 2? I am quite confused by the working of the code, and would appreciate if someone could just break it down step by step for me.

Thank you!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "jia yi Xu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljv7m5l01vv4yy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 95, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-26T13:06:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Edwyn Zhou", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukhlyq02239", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Mark Samuel", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk1qrnpwn0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-02T00:40:34Z", "content": "

The idea of the program is that multiplication by two moves all the bits one place to the left (towards the more significant digits), for example $$(1)_{10}=(01)_{2}$$ and $$(2)_{10}=(10)_{2}$$.

The loop eventually ends because the maximum number of digits in a number is finite on a computer, and the most significant digit signifies the sign of the number. Specifically, when the most significant digit is set to 1, the number is negative. See the following example where there are only four bits in an integer:

$$(0001)_2=1_{10}$$, multiplying by two gives $$(0010)_2=2_{10}$$, again gives $$(0100)_2=4_{10}$$, and a 4th time gives $$(1000)_2<0_{10}$$.

By counting the number of multiplications required to create a negative number, we can thus determine the number of bits in an integer.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-26T13:07:22Z", "content": "

{"history_size": 2, "folders": ["logistics"], "nr": 621, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-26T07:50:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uktgeon332e", "data": "lt2n33saq954zg", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-26T07:50:42Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lt2n38cteat59o", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-02-26T07:50:48Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lt2yysj2x793v", "to": "lt2n33s2wn34ze", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-26T13:23:16Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "data": "lt32siekg2s6t1", "to": "lt2n33s2wn34ze", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-26T15:10:21Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "data": "lt32tw2ol1a1g3", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-02-26T15:11:26Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lt2n33s2wn34ze", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-26T15:12:21Z", "cid": "lt32v2x4upp1ub", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "to": "lt2n33s2wn34ze", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-26T15:15:11Z", "cid": "lt32yqa8t2q1u8"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "data": "lt9cxbwapo97ii", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-02T00:40:39Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Void function return for midterm", "created": "2024-02-26T07:50:48Z", "content": "

For int and double and bool and other function types, I know what we have to use return to indicate what value to return. However, for a void function, I know we can write return; and it would be fine but not writing return is also fine as it'll automatically return by itself. However, from what i know, not including return is the more "technically right" way, but would we lose marks for writing return; in a void function? It is just a habit I have from working with functions, and technically it wouldn't affect the code in any way, but I just wanted to make sure it would be fine and we would not lose marks.

Thank you

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uktgeon332e", "subject": "Void function return for midterm", "created": "2024-02-26T07:50:42Z", "content": "

After compilation, every function has (at least) one return instruction, even those declared void, so I would argue its not any less correct to include a return statement. For example, a swap function will compile (x86, Windows) to something similar to the following :

// forme void(int*,int*)
échangerEntiers: 
	mov eax, [rcx]
	mov r8d, [rdx]
	mov [rdx], eax
	mov [rcx], r8d
	ret

You might also want to break out of the function early (invalid input), you can use an return before the end of the function for this :

void afficherMaximum(int* tab, int longueur) {
	if (longueur <= 0) return;
	// un boucle se trouve ici ...
}
"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-26T13:23:16Z", "content": "

// forme void(int*,int*)
échangerEntiers: 
	mov eax, [rcx]
	mov r8d, [rdx]
	mov [rdx], eax
	mov [rcx], r8d
	ret

You might also want to break out of the function early (invalid input), you can use an return before the end of the function for this :

	if (longueur <= 0) return;

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 624, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-26T16:10:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lt34xtews4f6vp", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-26T16:10:28Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "data": "lt354i8ij03bz", "to": "lt34xtenpul6vo", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-26T16:15:40Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "data": "lt355h6yw2u1y4", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-02-26T16:16:25Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "2023 Midterm Question 3", "created": "2024-02-26T16:10:28Z", "content": "

Could I get an explanation on what lines 5 and 6 of this code would do?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 78, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-26T16:15:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Hanna Bui", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul3hccbr41t", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "Siwei (Louis) He", "endorser": {"k51d87g8cyd16b": 1583114444, "ksee29v8k1s12w": 1631988612, "global": 1632777274, "ktc8hsydlh05eq": 1634833572, "ksgcyt7x1w23ll": 1635387538, "l80r9sofe8u6uk": 1666753584}, "admin": true, "photo": "1641699008_200.jpg", "id": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/j4qb3egsx7160h/1641699008_200.jpg", "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-26T16:16:25Z", "content": "

Note that q points to the address of the 6th element in arr.

The line p = q + 1 is essentially saying, p = q + 1 * sizeof(int), which is just the next location in memory. This means that p = &arr[6].

The same logic is used for p = q - 2: p = q - 2 * sizeof(int), which is two memory addresses back. This means that p = &arr[3].

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-26T16:15:40Z", "content": "

There is rounding that takes place when this format specifier is supplied to printf [1].

It is important to note that floating point operations use “round to nearest” (as defined by IEEE754 standard) in libc by default [2]. E.g. both 123.455 and 123.465 will be rounded to 123.46 if you use the format specifier “%.2lf”.
[1] https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_node/Floating_002dPoint-Conversions.html
[2] https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_node/Rounding.html
"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llyhj9awro63lb", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-26T16:52:34Z", "content": "There is rounding that takes place when this format specifier is supplied to printf [1].

It is important to note that floating point operations use “round to nearest” (as defined by IEEE754 standard) in libc by default [2]. E.g. both 123.455 and 123.465 will be rounded to 123.46 if you use the format specifier “%.2lf”.

[1] https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_node/Floating_002dPoint-Conversions.html
[2] https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_node/Rounding.html
"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llyhj9awro63lb", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-26T16:52:23Z", "content": "There is rounding that takes place when this format specifier is supplied to printf [1].

For this question, it says only one if is allowed, but I used an else if and else statement. The key used an elseif statement so I'm assuming if it asks for one if statement only, we are allowed to use elseif? Does thst mean we would also be allowed to use an else statement following that? Or would we be restricted to an if and elseif only?

Basically, would my answer be permitted since the key used an elseif but I used an elseif and else, and the question only asks for one if statement?

Thank you

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 97, "children": [{"history_size": 6, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-27T00:14:32Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Hanna Bui", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul3hccbr41t", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-02T00:33:11Z", "content": "

The condition while(1) always evaluates to true (since any nonzero number is equivalent to true. This means that the loop will continuously run, unless there's a statement that breaks out of it in its body.

The first if statement checks if you're at the end of array A (since a negative value, specifically -1, indicates you are at the end). If this is true, it then checks if you're at the end of array B. If both arrays are at the end, then the dot product is defined and you can return the sum. However, if you're not at the end of array B, arrB[i] < 0 evaluates to false, which means that B still has more elements, so their sizes don't match, so you return -1.

If the first check passes (if there's still more elements in array A), you still need to check if there are still more positive integers in array B, hence the second if statement. If the second if statement evaluates to false, then it means that array A still has more elements, but you're at the end of array B. This then means that the array sizes don't match, so you return -1.

If this second check also passes, then you would know that there's still more elements to process in arrays A and B, so you can continue computing the dot product.

This loop continues until both arrays end at the same time or if there's a size mismatch.

Statement 1 is illegal because p is a pointer and i is an integer, and you can't assign an integer value to a pointer (type mismatch).

Statement 2 is legal since you are dereferencing p, and that allows us to modify/access the value at its memory address. In this case, the value of i is assigned to the memory location that p points to.

Statement 3 is illegal since you are dereferencing q, but assigning it the memory address of i, and you can't assign an address to an integer (another type mismatch).

I am working on part one of the lab and encountering a problem when debugging my program. When I am looking at the first 20 characters in my array, they show up in the debugging tab on the left. However after the first 20 (index 19) they stop showing up.

This is what is looks like for the first 20, after every change, you see the new character. (when i=0)

Then when the second row is getting filled it no longer shows on the screen. (when i >0)

Is these a separate way to view 2d arrays? I can't find a separate setting under variables.

Hi,

We were taught to format scanf as

scanf(" %d", ptr); 

//instead of 

scanf("%d", ptr); 

in order to avoid some whitespace or unwanted garbage values being scanned in. Does this advice still apply to strings?

In other words:

scanf(" %s", ptr); 

//or

scanf("%s", ptr); //?

I ask because the textbook uses the second format and says whitespace will be ignored: 

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "String scanf leading white space", "created": "2024-03-01T01:16:18Z", "content": "

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["general_questions", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 79, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-01T02:17:16Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Toon Craps", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1700667274, "lqvcjvs6s457j1": 1709259422}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "l7peamq9ldd3rp", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-01T02:17:16Z", "content": "
