fixed^ i had to make the 10 into 11 instead. anyone know why?

Note that strings are null-terminated, meaning that the last character in the string is the null character (\0). When you're printing strings using the format specifier %s, it will print from the first element of your string to the first null character (exclusive).

However, when your column length is exactly as long as the longest word, there's not enough space for the null character (for those words that are as long). So when you're printing, it will continue to move onto the next element until it encounters a null character. That's why the column length should be the length of the longest string plus one.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-01T13:15:15Z", "content": "

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm", "general_questions", "final"], "nr": 665, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-04T13:39:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "ltczmrf96xm3ui", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-04T13:39:36Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "h7kosepaqa8en", "data": "ltd22lc2ey62qt", "to": "ltczmrf1n9q3uh", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-04T14:47:54Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "What are the grading critieria for exams?", "created": "2024-03-04T13:39:36Z", "content": "

For exams, do we recieve grades based on how close our code is to the code in the solution, or based on how close our output is to the expected one? Specifically, if we write very different code (still using only ideas taught in the course) to the solution that still works, do we get points for the question or not?

\n

\n

(I don't want to waste the time of the TA's if the rubric is based on the former with a remark request)

1. Since wordSize is a pointer variable it already has the correct type for scanf -- we want to store an integer so we need a pointer to an integer for the argument.


2. No, the code *(wordSize) is correct for accessing the stored value (it's a pointer to an integer so you need to use the dereference operator to retrieve the value) -- the warning here occurs because malloc takes an unsigned integer (i.e. positive), but there's a possibility that *(wordSize) stores a negative value (the input will always be a positive number but the int type doesn't guarantee this so the compiler can't be sure).

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm562039i1l1bg", "kfcinik3iit5s5", "ljv7m5l01vv4yy", "lm7ukrjw9d22xr"], "children": [], "id": "ltiqgxg0qby7hf", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["ljv7m5l01vv4yy"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltipg9vwgxj5ta", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716163020244, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lab7"], "nr": 694, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-08T18:20:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltizf5dij5b245", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-08T18:20:18Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "ltizucpk4b18q", "to": "ltizf5d8e86244", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-08T18:32:07Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Lab 7 - Declaring a 26 x 26 Array?", "created": "2024-03-08T18:20:18Z", "content": "

In the header for Lab 7, the board 2d array is defined as having 26 columns, rather than n columns (which we cannot change).

Also, in the instructions for declaring the board, it says not to "declare variable-length arrays":

Does this mean that we should be declaring a 26 x 26 array regardless of what the user inputs, then printing only the first n columns/rows of said array?

If so, what is the advantage of defining the array in this way, since we're already assuming that the user will give a valid input (ie. the user won't give a # too large to be stored in memory)? Wouldn't we be wasting memory to define a 26 x 26 array when a 4 x 4 array would have been sufficient?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab7", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "jia yi Xu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljv7m5l01vv4yy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 107, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-08T18:32:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Daniel Liu", "endorser": {"kex1d773m1q4wh": 1600385343, "keefchkgelh2ie": 1601352301, "kersxw4kjmi634": 1604633193, "global": 1604633193, "ks67upl5j2u636": 1638215275, "kxxhwvlztg1316": 1648301344, "kxrsgkty1i63uy": 1650402756, "l7jhttnojtu98": 1667170933, "lcl1hiw1lo02a5": 1678819708}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kevc7iza7in11p", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-08T18:32:07Z", "content": "This is most likely for our convenience. Though you won't be able to automatically format anything else (ie indents) by saving."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lmhs66fiwaq10n", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-09T00:07:06Z", "content": "In settings you can turn off formatting on a save entirely (under 'Text Editor' -> 'Formatting' -> 'Format On Save'). Though you won't be able to automatically format anything else (ie indents) by saving."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ltjbt4sqvnm4d6", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Right, so I want to keep format on save as it is quite helpful, but I want to modify the length it is wrapping at.", "created": "2024-03-09T00:09:17Z", "bucket_order": 8, "bucket_name": "Week 3/3 - 3/9", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "What does you settings.json file look like?", "created": "2024-03-09T00:34:32Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lmhs66fiwaq10n", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltjcsesirkq247", "updated": "2024-03-11T02:34:59Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "nvm, I figured it out. the style is a consequence of the "Google" formatting style that was overruling everything.", "created": "2024-03-09T00:35:26Z", "bucket_order": 8, "bucket_name": "Week 3/3 - 3/9", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltjctkuseyy7hn", "updated": "2024-03-09T00:35:26Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Tip: If you still want to use google formatting for everything else, go to settings.json and change this line:

"C_Cpp.clang_format_fallbackStyle": "Google"
to
"C_Cpp.clang_format_fallbackStyle": "{ BasedOnStyle: Google, ColumnLimit: 0 }"
everything else will stay the same but text wrap is turned off entirely (if you want text wrap to a different column number change 0 to 120 or something higher. google automatically has 80)

However, the test solution yields that 1,20 is prioritized over 2,1."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab6", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Rashaad Anwar", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukd2nhue1oz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 101, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-09T04:03:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevc7iza7in11p", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-09T04:06:31Z", "content": "checking the reference solution is always good.

(1,20) being prioritized over (2,1) would make sense.
Lowest row first and then lowest col

All you do is:

for r = 0; r < arrSize; r++:
\u00a0 \u00a0 for c = 0; c < arrSize; c++:
\u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 if puzzle[r][c] == word[0]:

It seems like when you're inputting the word puzzle, you're scanning all the characters (including the spaces). This means that the 2D array is also holding the spaces in between characters, which means that not all the letters are being scanned in.

You can add a space before the format specifier to ignore whitespace: scanf(" %c", ...);

Hello,

1) My algorithm doesnt use the given bool function but I have written another function that loops through all the points, checking if they are the current players color and if so running an 8 directional search for a series of opposite player pieces followed by a blank space. That blank space is then guaranteed to be a legal move and so the function records the row & col position in a 2d array to search through later to check for legal moves.

Doing this works perfectly but I have noticed my outpus are not coming out in the same order as the expected result, currently my algorithms loops through all the points, top-left to bottom-right and checks for all player color points in a counter clockwise rotation starting from south.

What exactly was the search order used to produce the example outputs in the lab7 documentation?

2) It is ok if I dont use the last two given functions? I've found much better alternative ways

That is not my question. I already have an efficient algorithm to get the all legal moves. The problem is that I don't know in which order the examples searched through them to get them.

In the 8 directional search, I start from south and turn 45 deg counter clockwise 7 times to search all direction. But if the example algorithm first did the 4 cardinal directions starting from south and then the 4 diagonals the outputs will be the same points, just in a different order.

The ordering is the problem. If I know in which order the expected search was done, I can alter my search to do it in the same order to get the expected prints.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["general_questions", "lab7"], "nr": 749, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-14T04:59:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltqrga5tps6w3", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-14T04:59:23Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "data": "ltr27vm06j14w6", "to": "ltqrga5itst6w2", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-14T10:00:47Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ltqrga5itst6w2", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-14T14:10:43Z", "cid": "ltrb5adk9ad49o", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ltqrga5itst6w2", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-14T14:11:39Z", "cid": "ltrb6i00eeh5ob", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ltqrga5itst6w2", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-14T14:23:12Z", "cid": "ltrblco7aho165", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ltqrga5itst6w2", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-14T14:25:25Z", "cid": "ltrbo72tgsp4sy", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "2D array size and declaration", "created": "2024-03-14T04:59:23Z", "content": "

Hi, I was doing lab 7, and I declared the 2D array board like this:

From my understanding, this 2D array would only have one row with 26 columns, with the first column filled with "\0" and the rest 25 columns automatically filled with "\0" as well. 
However, I found I can still access "row two" using the expression board[1][0], as seen in the debugger:

I want to check if my understanding is correct:

This is because the 2D array board is essentially a pointer, and the expression board[][] can access addresses that are not part of the 2D array board. 

Furthermore, I continued with my declaration of "char board[][26] = {'\0'};", and my "printBoard" function works. 

That means I changed the value in the address board[1][0], which is technically not part of the 2D array board, to 'U'. (If the board size is 4*4, then initially, row 2 column 1 would be 'U'.)

I wonder if this declaration is a bad coding style, as I am changing a value in a technically undeclared address and using that undeclared address in future codes. 

I also wonder if the values stored in these undeclared addresses may change midway during the program runs. 

Additionally, if I declare board like "char board[26][26] = {'\0'};", can I imagine the computer build a "fence" around all addresses of the 26*26 2D array in the main stack, where the values stored in these addresses can only be changed by the program. Whereas if I declare board like "char board[][26] = {'\0'};", I am going into "public space" when I am accessing board[1][0], and the addresses in the "public space" can be changed by other operations other than your program, which is unsafe. 

Just want to check if my understanding on this is accurate, thank you!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["general_questions", "lab7", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Aadavan Vasudevan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukt2fxpd31m", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 93, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-14T10:00:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-14T10:00:47Z", "content": "`char board [][26] = {'\0'};` is setting the intention that it is a 1 row with 26 columns 2D array. Accessing board[1][1] would be going outside the bounds of the array, and is indeed not correct. The debugger may allow it if the memory space is not used for something else in your computer. If you do so, your program has an undefined behavior. We can't predict what will happen. But this is indeed incorrect. It is not bad coding style. It is incorrect. If it works on your computer, it won't work on ECF. You must declare the array as `char board[26][26];` Your program can only access this 2D array, and no other process on your computer should be able to access your array."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ltr27vlmli4w3", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Im having the same problem, wouldn't chaning board[][26] go against what the reversi.h file declared and cause issues?", "created": "2024-03-14T14:10:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I keep printing out garbage characters such as these", "created": "2024-03-14T14:11:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltrb6i00eeh5ob", "updated": "2024-03-14T14:11:39Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Using an array to store the legal moves is possible like you mentioned as it provides other benefits as well.

If you dont want that you may have to check every single tile, top-left to bottom-right, and print legal ones as you go. Far from perfect but very usable.

Assuming the algorithm stops at the earliest times, worst case for the brute force check would be about 26x26x8 = 5,408 checks which is not that bad of a worst case.

Hint: for loop

Thanks for the all the good comments. However, my code has already implemented the for-loop and able to print available moves. I am not sure if my algorithm works differently than it should have. To briefly explain my algorithm, I first look for the available moves for white tiles (for example), my code would traverse 2D array and looks for white tile and checks direction -> if legal -> then print the location of the available moves. The problem in this case is that although I can print all the available moves, they are not in the order of increasing rows, then in order of increasing columns. Because my algorithm will look for very first "white" tiles and print the available moves for this specific tile (this will be the first available move appear in the terminal). To simply put, this available move, for example, has position of (ee), which will be printed first. However, the white tiles appearing afterwards may have available moves in the position of (aa). In this case, my output will be:

ee

aa

At this point, I can't really think of any methods besides declaring a new 2D array to store the available moves for each colour and sort them, and print them. I was just wondering if there is a better way to do it rather than declaring a new 2D array.

I essentially have the same algorithm.
> Start from one color
> Check each direction until you find an opposite color

> keep going until you hit your own color again(break) or until you hit a free space (legal space)
> store the row and col of the legal space in a 2D array but also store the inverse of the direction I went.

If I went west from a white tile to find a legal space, I store the row and col but also store the direction of east.

I sort it with regards to the index, loop through the array again to display them but also make sure to not print duplicate (row, col)

This way, when executing the "play move" algorithm I can start from a space I know is legal, and just go in that direction I already know I'll meet a same colored tile in. Keep filling in the tiles I'm on until I get to another tile that is the same color.

So the time it takes to sort them is a trade off to have a faster "play move" algorithm  

Full algorithm is too detailed to fully explain so I hope this helps. Since you already sound like you are gonna implement a legalMoves array, better make use of its benefits too.

Hi,

Although I am hugely inexperienced in programming, I love the leaderboard feature. 

I was just wondering how the teaching team would ensure that students do not simply search online for the 'smartest' algorithms and copy? Are there checks for ingenuity? It would be a shame for my small program to be mauled by the most competitive algorithm out there which wasn't made by a student. 

Sorry if my concern is misplaced; again, this is my first programming course. 

Thanks

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 143, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-14T21:24:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Toon Craps", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1700667274, "lqvcjvs6s457j1": 1709259422}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-14T21:24:56Z", "content": "

The rules for the leaderboard say that a move should take, at max, 1 second to compute by an algorithm on the ecf server or your lose on a time out (0 Points).

Most of these 'smart algorithms' online use some sort of tree search algorithm (MCTS for example). These algorithms are 'smart' because they can create a tree of possible future positions and search through them to some depth to find the overall most advantageous branch and choose moves as such.

This means even though for example, I'd like to use a tree search to look ahead, the depth at which these trees can look into will be pretty limited because of the time constraint as tree searches indeed have strong performance but not usually very fast calculation times.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-14T21:24:01Z", "content": "

The rules for the leaderboard say that a move should take, at max, 1 second to compute by an algorithm on the ecf server or your lose on a time out (0 Points).

Most of these 'smart algorithms' online use some sort of tree search algorithm (MCTS for example). These algorithms are 'smart' because they can create a tree of possible future positions and search through them to some depth to find the overall most advantageous branch and choose moves as such.

This means even though for example, I'd like to use a search tree to look ahead, the depth at which these trees can look into will be pretty limited because of the time constraint as tree searches indeed have strong performance but not usually very fast calculation times.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukr1754d2wl"], "children": [], "id": "ltrqmj7axsg1ef", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

", "created": "2024-03-14T22:20:41Z", "bucket_order": 8, "bucket_name": "Week 3/10 - 3/16", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "To follow up, would we be allowed to research best practices/algorithms or is the intention that we develop the program fully on our own (i.e. without any online searching)? ", "created": "2024-03-14T22:22:05Z", "bucket_order": 8, "bucket_name": "Week 3/10 - 3/16", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltrsp7fv89z59u", "updated": "2024-03-14T22:22:05Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

I can't really think of a good way to make a competent reversi algorithm without trees, but sure if there is you probably can. The problem with getting the code from the internet is that most of the time any programmer will first look to the internet to see if anybody else solved the same problem you are trying solve first.

Because of this, 'most optimal algorithm' for something is usually known and the code behind it understood very well. At that point  there is no real reason to not use an already known, good algorithm that is known to be efficient.

Thus the problem with detecting code from the internet is that most efficient algorithms will most likely look a like one another if not be written the same as there is no need to improve or change it most of the time. When an algorithm is optimized enough, there is no real reason to tweak or add it something from yourself. As doing so will most likely just make it slover or less efficient

Though for us, the time limit means some changes are in order to speed up/cut corners with the most widely used game algorithms.

If you want to research stuff you can check out an algorithm type called "MinMax algorithm with alpha/beta pruning". It sounds scarier than it is. That's what I'll be going for so hopefully I can speed it up a bit.

", "created": "2024-03-14T22:47:12Z", "bucket_order": 8, "bucket_name": "Week 3/10 - 3/16", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltrtlhwoc995ze", "updated": "2024-03-14T22:47:12Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltrsneapjt01oq", "updated": "2024-03-14T22:47:21Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-15T00:23:58Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Toon Craps", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1700667274, "lqvcjvs6s457j1": 1709259422}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Lily Chen", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llgvmgp9ws25xe", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Deena Abrari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukrjw9d22xr", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevc7iza7in11p", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-15T00:23:58Z", "content": "

You can indeed search online for some "smart algorithms".

Very famous ones are alpha beta pruning with a decision tree. 

You can try implementing this and set a time limit for < 1 second.

This is allowed.

When I took aps105 3 years ago, a lot of tips and tricks were actually to either 

1. Search up strategies on how to win reversi

2. Read academic papers on how to win reversi (parameter tuning with alpha beta pruning and what not).

You'll get in big trouble if you simply copy the "source code" from online. Academic integrity software detectors blah blah will catch that as well as more than likely another student will have done the same. However, you can search up what alpha beta pruning is or a "smart algorithm" for reversi and try and code this up. Or you can do number 1 and code up these strategies. Or you can try coming up with your own heuristics and seeing if it works

"published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevc7iza7in11p", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-15T06:35:41Z", "content": "how do you study for your calculus course?

The suggested method to study for this course is probably just to do a crap ton of practice exams. If not these exams, just do a crap ton of programming practice in general and you\u2019ll be able to still solve the exams. The course is not really theoretical in the sense of your math classes but more so application and hands on based.\u00a0

I know some students who have no programming experience who blew that midterm out of the park and all they did was the past midterms and spent minimal time on reviewing, rereading, rewriting notes. I didn\u2019t have any programming experience either when I took aps105 in 2020, I followed the same pattern.

Chances are, you won\u2019t need to review much stuff in your notes for this class because i\u2019m sure you rmr how to declare an integer variable. It\u2019s all about practice and actually doing the questions yourself where you\u2019ll be able to excel in this class.

There have been courses I\u2019ve taken my 3 years at uoft where I was able to just reread some notes and review concepts i didnt understand and I would do fine on the test. APS105 is not one of them\u00a0

So if I were to do free(address of second element of array) would it free memory past the end of the array since it is tailored to the number input to malloc? ", "created": "2024-03-15T03:58:31Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

don't do that. the chunk of memory you allocated is considered a complete chunk. You shouldn't just free part of it. Always free the whole chunk.

Free in the middle of the chunk will give you undefined behavior.

", "created": "2024-03-15T03:59:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mark Samuel", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk1qrnpwn0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Hanna Bui", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul3hccbr41t", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7uk1qrnpwn0", "lm7ul3hccbr41t"], "id": "lts4rfixwtq4sj", "updated": "2024-03-16T01:11:20Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Check C language standard: https://port70.net/%7Ensz/c/c11/n1570.html#7.22.3.3p2

2 The free function causes the space pointed to by ptr to be deallocated, that is, made available for further allocation. If ptr is a null pointer, no action occurs. Otherwise, if the argument does not match a pointer earlier returned by a memory management function, or if the space has been deallocated by a call to free or realloc, the behavior is undefined.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lab7"], "nr": 779, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-15T16:41:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltsvyy88l4j4a8", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-15T16:41:25Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "data": "ltt1scpyyb9353", "to": "ltsvyy804xz4a6", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-15T19:24:15Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Lab 7 procedure clarification", "created": "2024-03-15T16:41:25Z", "content": "

Hello,

I just wanted to clarify what our program is supposed to do. I understood that there are two scenarios in which the user's move is either valid or invalid. 

Valid: The user enters a move and the program prints out the new board accounting for this move.

Invalid: The user enters an invalid move and the program prints out "Invalid move" followed by the unchanged board.

And once one of these two scenarios occurs the program will end, as the program will not continuously prompt the user. This is my understanding of the program, and I am asking if it is correct. 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab7", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 101, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-15T19:24:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Ruth Fasil", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llzr7adf3zk2u8", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-15T19:24:15Z", "content": "Yes your understanding is correct."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["llzr7adf3zk2u8"], "children": [], "id": "ltt1scpqaul352", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltsvyy804xz4a6", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716163110871, "default_anonymity": "no"}

You only need to flip based on the user input right?

Would probably look something like this:

Input move check if it's a legal move below:

legalMoveFunction:

Check if move is in bounds

Check if it's an empty tile

Check all 8 directions with checkLegalInDirection. If legal, flip it (call flip function)
If all 8 directions are illegal or not in bounds or not empty then it's not legal

flipFunction:

//By this point, should already know which direction to flip in

board[rowOfInputtedMove][colOfInputtedMove] = colour

iterate in the direction that is legal until we hit our own colour (deltaRow and deltaCol stuff similar logic to checkLegalInDirection fucntion)

Hello, I am currently finishing up on lab7, however when I was submitting my code against the test cases I noticed a strange phenomenon. 

I have passed all of the other 3/4 test cases, however when the user enters in a large board size (ex. around anything larger than 21), random B's start appearing on my board. 

For example, this is what the initial board layout looks like on the ECF servers, before board configuration. 

Compared to a smaller board size, which works perfectly fine:

What's even more interesting is that, depending on what device I compile/run it on, I get phantom B's at different places. 

For example, on my own laptop, I get a lesser amount of Phantom B's (i.e. just one) and it's always at the (u,r) coordinate, regardless of the board input size. 

Originally I thought it might be something to do with my code, however, seeing as how the output is inconsistent among different devices, I'm really not sure how to debug this. 

If anyone has any advice on how I might be able to fix this it would be greatly appreciated.

Hello, I ran the two examples in the doc locally on my Mac and they seemed to give the desired output. However, when I ran the same code on the ECF an output resulted which repeated the available moves randomly (resulting in failed test cases). What could be the reason for this? I assume it could possibly have something to do with the number of people on ECF since the remote connection is very slow at this time. Help would be greatly appreciated.

@419 very likely due to illegal memory access

Salma: It has nothing to do with many people on ECF. It has to do either with uninitialized variables that your Mac set to 0, or accessing illegal memory space, which your Mac can allow. Some errors in your code result in undefined behaviour and it can result in different behaviour on your Mac and ECF.

1. check if it is possible to change tiles in a direction

2. if it is possible, loop through the same direction and flip tiles

^ repeat 8 times (for all directions)

Hello, for my part 2 algorithm I plan to create and traverse a tree of game states. 

1) For a "addChild()" function, I'd need to resize the child array of a parent Node as I initially define it as a sizeless array. For this I use

realloc().
I know we have not covered this but If I can I'd like to use it.

2) I don't plan on using so much but besides a computation time (1s) does the code have a memory restriction? As in the total memory it can use up during run time.
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 104, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-21T00:10:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Salma Emara", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": "1675320204_200.jpg", "id": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/jlzv60dhucu1fm/1675320204_200.jpg", "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "j4qb3egsx7160h", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-21T00:10:46Z", "content": "

1) you can use realloc. It is included in the standard C library.

2) You will likely run out of runtime before memory.

Quick help with this matter would be greatly appreciated.

Hi, I'm having difficulties setting up my device for lab8part2. 

1. I don't know how to properly add the liblab8part2.a file to my VS Code directory. I downloaded the file on my device, but I can't open it, and I can't copy and paste it into my folder. 

2. After we add the .a file, can we fully set up the project if, instead of going to the settings.json, we just run these lines of code:

gcc reversi.c -L. -llab8part2 -std=c99 -o lab8part2

./lab8part2

I tried running the first line in the Powershell and it just caused an error, but I assume that's because I haven't added the .a file yet. 

Edit: Ok I figured it out, I had to add the file individually to my downloads again before dragging and dropping.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Setting up Lab 8 Part 2", "created": "2024-03-27T01:48:25Z", "content": "

Lab 8 Part 1

Q- Does it happen when there are no valid moves for B and W?

When it’s W’s turn and it has no valid moves, print that it has no valid moves. Same for B.

In our test cases, it won’t happen that both have no valid moves and the board has unoccupied locations. Both will have no valid moves when the board is full. Then, print who is the winner, without saying W and B has no valid moves.

Q- If I want to submit only lab8 part 1, I get a timestamp error. What do I do?

A- It is not an error. @945

Lab 8 Part 2

Q- My code is not compiling with the liblab8part2.a. What did I do wrong?

A- Common fixes:

a.) If you are on Windows, it won't work as we didn't provide a library for Windows. Please ECF for this part. You can compile, run and debug your code then.

b.) If you are working on ECF, please copy the liblab8part2.a from linux64bit folder. 

c.) If you decide to have your lab8part2.h, reversi.c, liblab8part2.h and liblab8part2.a in ~aps105/lab8/lab8part2 folder, then in settings.json you need to put in \"${workspaceFolder}/lab8/lab8part2/liblab8part2.a\", instead of \"${workspaceFolder}/liblab8part2.a\". This is assuming your VS Code has opened the aps105 directory. 

Q- Do I need to have only one function called makeMove?

A- No! You can have as many functions as you want as long as they are all called in makeMove.

You will only submit your makeMove function and any functions it calls in lab8part2.c. 

Lab 8 Part 3

Q- I can't see my updates on leaderboard. What's wrong?

A- @1017

That is common.

I would say try testing your code on ECF with smarter and smartest and observe where it fails.You may use the debugger on ECF too.

I have seen this to be caused by using uninitialized variables or accessing elements outside the bounds of the array.

I also have this same issue. I am doing all of my development on ECF, and when testing by myself on ECF, I my program beats all 4 cases (W against smarter, B against smarter, W against smartest, B against smartest)

However, when I try to submit it, it says I can only pass test case 7 (the first one for lab8part2). I'm wondering why the results of the submission are different from the ones I am testing since both are happening on ECF. 

I'd appreciate if anyone from the teaching team could help me out.

", "created": "2024-03-30T03:14:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Hey, I have a similar issue. We're you able to figure out what's wrong?", "created": "2024-03-30T16:00:36Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_2", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luea489m8md1ru", "updated": "2024-03-30T16:00:36Z", "config": {"editor": "md"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Yes, I realized what was the issue. When I was testing it on my own in ECF, the program returned that my computer "won", but upon further investigation, my computer won using illegal moves. 

To fix this, I added an if-statement to check if what my algorithm returned was a valid move. If it was, then proceed as normal, but if it wasn't, then I just returned the next valid move (regardless of its score or value). 

In summary, my personal tests were winning through illegal moves, which explains why it failed the submission tests. Hope that helps.

", "created": "2024-03-30T16:27:42Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Salma Emara", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": "1675320204_200.jpg", "id": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/jlzv60dhucu1fm/1675320204_200.jpg", "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["jlzv60dhucu1fm"], "id": "lueb33jdaks2vx", "updated": "2024-03-30T18:03:51Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Hello I am a different person. I am wondering how you knew it was through illegal moves or how you can find out you are making illegal moves. This may or may not be a silly question but shouldn't the manual testing detect whether or not you are making illegal or legal moves? Thank you. ", "created": "2024-03-30T17:38:02Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_3", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luedljoig2f1wa", "updated": "2024-03-30T17:38:02Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

That's a very valid question. I found out it was  illegal moves by scrolling all the way up and carefully looking at what moves my computer was making. I realized the very first move was an illegal move, and maybe some of the later ones too (you don't need to check for all of them, just the fact that one illegal move was made)

How did it go past the checks already in place, you ask? This has to do with how the makeMove function works. You have to initialize a row and col in main and pass their addresses to the makeMove function. I initialized row and col both to zero, meaning that if my makeMove function could not find a suitable row/col, the original row and col declared outside the function still remained at row = 0 and col = 0 (since they were not modified by makeMove function).

This meant that sometimes the very first move my computer made was the illegal move at the top left of the board (move aa). 

As for how I fixed this, in the makeMove function I checked if the row and col were valid before passing it on to main. I hope it makes sense.

For lab 8, there are test cases for lab 8 part 1 that are worth 6 marks and 8 marks for lab 8 part 2.  

The 8 marks for lab 8 part 2 you will know how much you get when you submit your code. There are 4 test cases that are run. Two of them play your makeMove function against smarter and two against smartest. 

The two games are played against smarter with the computer playing with B and another time with W. We also run your code against smartest with 2 games. 

Each game is worth 2 marks.

when I try to run my code, why my code always jumps over this scanf. I mean when I run the code, my code doesn’t ask me to scanf the letter.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 67, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-29T02:52:53Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Pinhao Ding", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukwsz1dl3e7", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-29T02:53:16Z", "content": "

It could be because there is a newline character in the input buffer after your first scanf() statement. When the second scanf() is run, it is storing the newline character instead of inputting 'B' or 'W'.

To fix this, you should put a space before the format specifier to ignore any whitespaces (newline characters, spaces. etc...): scanf(" %c", ...);

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-29T02:52:53Z", "content": "

It could be because there is a newline character in the input buffer after your first scanf() statement. When the second scanf() is run, it is storing the newline character instead of inputting 'B' or 'W'.

To fix this, you should put a space before the format specifier to ignore any whitespaces (newline characters, spaces. etc...): scanf(" %c", ...);

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lab8"], "nr": 918, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-29T16:24:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lucviufujj23xh", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-29T16:24:17Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lucweu683i4h3", "to": "lucviufmw0i3xg", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-29T16:49:10Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Lab8 Part2 Question", "created": "2024-03-29T16:24:17Z", "content": "

Hi, I have two questions regarding this part:

1. Do we have to consider the case where our colour has no available moves? What should the row and col be in that case (e.g. NULL?)

2. Also, should our makeMove() function detect if the game has ended? For example, if the game ends but this function still returns a row & col , does that mean we lose the game?

Thanks!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab8", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Ethan Wang Jan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukhvugp424e", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Mehul Garg", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukexwtu31u9", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Suzen Bao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukh5cyqz224", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 80, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-29T16:49:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Suzen Bao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukh5cyqz224", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-29T16:49:10Z", "content": "No, you do not have to consider either case. This is because your function will only be called when there is a valid move to be played. As for when the game ends, when your algorithm is tested, it will be placed into a fully functional game in which when the game is over will be accounted for.

quick answer: No, the structure of the game when testing your function will account for both 1 and 2.
"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukh5cyqz224"], "children": [], "id": "lucweu5y3zhh2", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukhvugp424e", "lm7ukexwtu31u9", "lm7ukh5cyqz224"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lucviufmw0i3xg", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716163254234, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Hello, 

I am starting lab8 part2 and am a little confused on how to get started. This is my current understanding:

1. While developing the code, your main function calls on the smartMove function and then refers to the makeMove function for the computer to make a move. Therefore, the whole code for lab8part2 includes the main function and the makeMove function. If I want to refer to another function in my main function, like for example, a function called computerMove, computerMove must be located in the makeMove function (per the lab 8 instructions). Therefore, do I have to call makeMove first and then call computerMove in the makeMove function.

It's sort of difficult to explain, but what am I supposed to have in the main function for part2; just a call on smartMove and makeMove? Should all other function calls I had in part1 be called in the makeMove function (ie. rearrange my whole code to account for this)

2. In the makeMove function, what do row and col stand for and why are they integer pointers? If I call on the makeMove function, am I taking in smartMove's row and columns as input or does the input mean something else?

Any clarification would be extremely helpful.

edit: does makeMove only choose a position for the computer to move? The main function /other functions in ECF are therefore only to test our code, so why do all our other functions need to be moved inside makeMove function for submission (will they even be called when being tested)?

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Lab8part2 MakeMove confusion", "created": "2024-03-29T17:47:27Z", "content": "

makeMove saves the best move. So it saves it inside *row and *col. That's why they are pointers. It chooses the position for your computer to move.

You need your other functions inside makeMove to presumably help you find out what the best move is

I overhauled my entire code and now it seems to be working. While I am not entirely sure of the exact issue, if I had to guess, it was probably because of an invalid move my bot was making and which I seemed to miss in my manual checks of my program.

For those also having this issue, try backtracking your bot's moves and ensure there are no out-of-bound moves being done or illegal moves made. If you are using recursion, try changing the number of recursive loops you are doing and see if that causes any issues. While this is very tedious, I believe it might be the source of your failed test case.

And what would happen if our updated code doesn’t pass all the test cases but our first one did?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lab8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 80, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-30T02:12:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-30T02:14:15Z", "content": "

Lab 8 part 2 is used for grading. I suggest you submit the code that passes test cases here to get t grades. 

Lab 8 part 3 is for being there on the leaderboard, and possibly getting a certificate if you rank high there. It is ungraded. 

Your algorithm in each part can be different. You need to win against smarter and smartest to rank on the leaderboard.

Does it return the exact index it found both letters. Example: lets say s1=banana and s2 = lama. will it return 1 because the index is the same at 1"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["general_questions", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 61, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-30T03:52:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Salma Emara", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": "1675320204_200.jpg", "id": "jlzv60dhucu1fm", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/jlzv60dhucu1fm/1675320204_200.jpg", "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0w6sz9wqg54e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-30T03:54:07Z", "content": "

The strncmp(s1, s2, n) and strcmp(s1, s2) functions compares two strings. It returns three different types of integers:

  • Returns an integer less than 0 when s1 comes before s2 in the dictionary.
  • Returns 0 when s1 and s2 are the same.
  • Returns an integer greater than 0 when s1 comes after s2 in the dictionary.

In your example, strcmp(s1, s2) will return an integer that is less than 0, since "banana" comes before "lama" in the dictionary. This section of the textbook describes it in detail: https://learningc.org/chapters/chapter10-strings/string-functions#comparing-strings

I had this same issue and if it there was a runtime error, the submission would let you know. I fixed mine by making sure that I was actually modifying the pointers 'row' and 'col' correctly by subtracting each of the values they were pointing to by 1 to ensure that the dereferenced number reflects the actual indices of the 2D board array. (Ex. if you wanted to make the move 'ab', then you want to ensure *row = 0 and *col = 1).

Hope this helps!

(Ex. if you wanted to make the move 'ab', then you want to ensure *row = 0 and *col = 1).
